PUNNICHY, Sask,
May 28, 1946.

J.P.B.Ostrander Esq., Inspector of Indian Agencies, Regina, Sask.

Mr. Hick, Teacher at Day Star Day School has a car, but there is no garage there for him to put it in.

I am enclosing herewith, requisition for supplies of materials etc., required for the construction of a garage, and if the Department sees fit to authorize this, I would be glad.

R.S.Davis,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I am enclosing herewith copy of letter and requisition forms in connection with the erection of a small garage for the use of the day school teacher at the Day Star Day School of the Touchwood Agency, at a cost of $77.65. Included in the requisition is also an amount of $10.00, being the cost of cutting, trimming, and erecting a flag pole on the school grounds.

I would recommend that authority be granted for the flag pole but I do not recommend the erection of the garage at the expense of our Department. It is a small matter but would create a precedent which would result in a request for garages for privately owned cars at most of the other places and I do not think that we should build on school premises the kind of a shack which Mr. Hicks has in mind in asking for this one.

I would recommend that he be given permission to erect a small garage at his own expense and that when he leaves the school he be permitted to dispose of it as he sees fit.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, June 5, 1946.

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
414 Federal Building, Regina, Saskatchewan.

With reference to your letter of the 30th ultimo, the Department approves an expenditure of $10.00 covering the cost of securing and erecting a flagpole at the Day Star Indian Day School.

It has not been our practice to erect a garage at an Indian day school, and I agree with the decision that you have made regarding Mr. Hick's request.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

EXD.

I enclose herewith requisition for supplies, in triplicate, for material and labor for repairs and re-decorating the Day Star Indian Day School and residence. Also for storm windows for replacement.

If the Department cannot do all this work this year, possibly half of the work on the house could be left until next year, but the work on the school should be done.

When Mr. Taylor was teacher at the school he had the storm windows left all over the place and some of these got broken. Those requested are to replace these.

R.S. Davis,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

Enclosed find copy of Indian Agent Davis' letter and requisitions for material and labour re decorating the Day Star Indian School and residence.

I would recommend that this be approved.

J.P.R. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Day Star Indian Day School.

Superintendent Logie's report on the above Day School has been received here. His comments on the whole are satisfactory and he has the following remarks to make about the teacher:

"The situation may be summed up thus: Mr. Hick has the confidence and affection of his pupils but his teaching methods leave much to be desired.

"Of course it is always a problem in such schools to find someone who combines the qualities which gain the confidence of the Indians together with the best teaching techniques. Further would such a paragon be content to live in isolation in order to teach these children?

"It is my opinion, in the light of these facts, that Mr. Hick is doing a fair job, for he has the primary requisite, a love for and the confidence of the children.

"The children are being instructed much in the same way as Mr. Hick was taught, as far as I could learn. But the test shows that they are learning to read, to write quite neatly, to handle the English language to some extent, both oral and written, and to do simple arithmetic. (The test papers and record sheet are being forwarded under separate cover. [Progressive Achievement Test]).

With regard to the condition of the building he has the following comments to make:

..... "Before
"Before another winter storm windows ought to be provided for the main northern exposure windows. With insulation this would make the school much more comfortable. This winter, using wood only, the school was difficult to heat and the teacherage was used instead at times.

"I found the classroom floor untidy as was the basement also.

"Sanitary facilities need improving as follows:

(a) Wash stands, instead of makeshift boxes, to encourage the children to keep clean. The girls have a room set apart for them in the teacherage and a few added facilities of this kind would be welcomed. The boys need more encouragement along this line than the girls.

(b) Drinking water. Snow was being used when I visited. It was melted on the teacherage stove. In the summer a large wooden barrel is used and the water is hauled. The barrel is extremely unsanitary and at present is so dried out as to be useless. Some attention to this problem is urgent.

"Six chair desks are used but 20 more are needed. The other desks are in poor condition and do not fit the children."

In conclusion he makes the following remarks:

"In general, there is a happy atmosphere and the children are learning.

"It is my opinion that the situation at this school could be much improved in the following ways:

(1) Insulate school, provide storm windows, better sanitary facilities.

(2) Provide more reading material 'children's books'."
especially for grade 2, 3 levels. At present there is not much more than the readers.

(3) Provide Mr. Hick with professional books or magazines on improved teaching techniques."

Would you please see that a requisition is submitted for the desks required, being certain to indicate the sizes needed. Desks come in small, medium and large sizes.

We would also like to have your ideas with regard to the improvement of the sanitary facilities and also with regard to the storm windows. If Mr. Hick will requisition for the library books which will be described in the next issue of the Bulletin, he will be able to start a small school library, as recommended.

Bernard F. Henry,
Superintendent of Education.

re Day Star Day School

With reference to your letter 121-2-1 dated April 20, 1948, regarding Inspector's report, we had storm windows for this school but through neglect of the past teacher, they were not taken care of and got broken. I tried to have these repaired last fall, but could not get glass. However, I will get in a requisition before the winter comes.

Regarding the untidiness of the school, Mr. Hick is a bachelor, and gets careless. I have taken this matter up with him and he has promised to do better in future.

(A) Regarding the wash stands, there is very little room in this school to put these in. On my next visit, I will see what can be done and make a recommendation.

(B) The water situation at this school has never been good. We have dug six wells without getting any adequate water supply.

For the past year I have been having the water hauled from a well a mile and a quarter north west of the school, in a barrel. However since your letter I have ordered two large cream cans which should be much more sanitary, and should overcome this problem for the time being. I am also enclosing a requisition for a drinking fountain.

As it will be necessary for us to build a teacherage, as the old building is not worth spending much money on, and has no basement, I would recommend that this school be moved a mile and a quarter north west where we can get water, and a new teacherage built. This should be done next year as do not think Mr. Hick can carry on more than a year or so as his health is not good, and a married couple would be more suitable.

If this suggestion meets with your approval, please advise me and I will see that the amount for the school is included in the 1949-50 estimates.
The desks in this school that was mentioned in the Inspector's report are the old style and are not much different to the ones used in other schools. While these children are growing out of the desks, it will not be long before a smaller group will come along and fit the desks. However, I will forward a requisition for your consideration.

I have taken the matter of reading material for grades two and three level, and Mr. Hick will be requisitioning for these in due course.

At the DAY STAR Reserve we found Mr. Hick enjoying his work. He has done much to improve the appearance of the place since he went there and in our opinion he is doing a very good job of work. Although we have not been advised by your Department of the School Inspector's Report on Mr. Hick, we understand that it was a very satisfactory one. I wish to make the following observations. The school is very difficult to heat in the wintertime and Mr. Hick has to take the youngest of the children to his residence because it is too cold for them to play in the school during the noon hour. There are no storm windows on the school despite the fact that this need has been made known to the Department of Indian Affairs for some time. The teacher's residence at Day Star requires a lot of work to be done to it before it can be made warm and comfortable. The interior is badly in need of paint and calamine and nothing was done to it before Mr. Hick took over the work as teacher. There is no supply of drinking water which has to be hauled to the school during winter and summer.

The Indian Department expects Mr. Hick to provide the twenty-six children with a hot noon-day meal each day. The grant made to him for this work is approximately $8.00 per month, while the actual cost to Mr. Hick for feeding the children is $25.00. Incidentally out of the $8.00 per month, Mr. Hick is expected to provide brooms and soap, etc., for cleaning purposes at the school.

Attached hereto is Form 37 listing materials required and an estimate of the labour required to repair the cement work.

Mr. Lathi did not care to submit a tender for labour on this work as it is not possible to determine the extent of damage under the cement floor.

Authority is requested to purchase the repair materials locally at a cost of $37.72 and employ a contractor to do the work at a cost of approximately $56.00

Sir:

In reply to your letter above referred to relative to opening a Day School on the Fishing Lake Reserve, I would state that I will send a detailed estimate of the cost of a school building by our next mail, but I would ask if the department has fully considered the advisability of building a day school where the Indians state that they do not want a school, and where they state that if one is built they will not send their children to school; and as these Indians lead a nomadic life they are seldom to be found on their Reserve, except in the winter, and besides there are only about seven families or 50 persons in all, who live on this Reserve.

I would prefer to see some one as a Missionary go and live on the Reserve for a time and then get his views on the advisability of

The Indian Commissioner,

Regina.
of having a school, and where it should be situated. From what I have seen of the Nut and Fishing Lake Band I firmly believe that for Missionary work it would be the most difficult field in the Territories and would therefore require a first class man.

I understand that the Rev. A.C. Kettle of the Church of England has been nominated by the Bishop of Qu'Appelle as School teacher and Missionary at Fishing Lake. As he does not understand their language nor habits, being I understand, only a short time in this Country, he has a bigger contract than he anticipates, and there are nine chances out of ten that he will fail, and it might be well to see what can be done before building a school.

It would be impossible to build the school by the first of May next.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

MEMORANDUM FOR THE INFORMATION OF THE SUPERINTENDENT GENERAL RELATIVE TO ATTACHED LETTER FROM THE BISHOP OF QU'APPELLE.

Re Industrial School in the diocese.

1. Industrial Schools have not been established with relation to particular dioceses, and the Church of England has control of its full share as compared with other denominations,—in fact, more than any other excepting the Roman Catholic.

For the best interests of the pupils it is regarded as beneficial to have them at a distance from the interruptions and influences attending proximity to the Reserves, and they are situated at the most eligible points throughout the country, and in numbers which have caused difficulty in procuring the grants necessary for their maintenance as part of an educational system which has steadily increased in extent and cost until it has assumed large proportions. Concessions have been made relative to a Boarding School at Touchwood Hills in consideration of there being no Industrial Institution connected with the English Church nearer than Elkhorn, which, however, sufficiently meets the necessities of the case.

His Lordship has seen the wisdom of— as he states—refraining from pressing for this.
2. Funds to complete and maintain Industrial School at Medicine Hat.

His Lordship recently stated that he accepted without complaint the Department's refusal to make provision in the Estimates for maintenance of pupils unless the Church would guarantee the completion of the building, which refusal was the result of provision made during several consecutive years, having been unused in consequence of the failure of the Church authorities to mature their plans. The idea of establishing a school at Medicine Hat originated with Rev. Mr. Wilson, whose habit it was to act independently, and selected the point which the undersigned would have opposed, had he been consulted, and has never been able to view favourably, and it is significant that the Bishop of Calgary and Saskatchewan, in whose diocese the building is, has never been disposed to connect himself with the undertaking, but pressed for the Institution recently established at Calgary.

3. Establishment of Day Schools at Fishing Lake Reserve.

Despite the new established policy being to reduce rather than increase the number of Day Schools which Industrial and Boarding Schools are intended to take the place of as far as possible, and despite the very poor prospects for getting these particular Indians to avail themselves of a school which they say they do not want, and the Department having refused applications from other denominations, at His Lordship's urgent
urgent solicitation a promise was made that if by the first of the current month the teacher were provided the Department would pay the usual amount of $300 per annum towards his salary, but little if any hope of being able to provide a school building was held out, before provision should have been made in the Supplementary Estimates.

In fulfilment of this promise provision has been made in Supplementary Estimates for 1896-97 for a schoolhouse and salary grant.

The Department communicated with the Indian Commissioner as to cost of schoolhouse, but said that it did not at present see its way to authorize the expenditure, but said nothing about inability to implement its promise of a salary grant from the beginning of the current month, and probably there has arisen some confusion at the Regina Office between the two things, and its attention is being drawn to the matter, so that there is nothing to prevent His Lordship from proceeding in accordance with the terms of the promise just described.

Extract from Mr. Inspector Graham's report on the Touchwood Hills Agency visited during the last week of October.

I am not making a special report on the Fishing Lake Day school, but have the following suggestions to make with regard to it.

As the Indians of this reserve have apparently made up their minds to settle down to work at farming, I believe that a good day school could be worked up. I would point out that the present school is a small log structure, poorly built, cold and cheerless, and now that the Indians are farming in another locality, the school is not conveniently situated.

If the Department could come to some arrangement with the Anglican Church authorities, whereby the school could be run on a public school basis, under a properly qualified male teacher, appointed and paid by the Department, I am sure good results would follow, especially as such a teacher would have the assistance of our energetic Farmer in helping the work along. If this change is made I would strongly recommend that a new frame school-house be built near the farm buildings, surrounding which are the Indian farms, where most of the children live. I am satisfied a good school could be built for $1200.

I do not consider that a day school has had a fair trial on this reserve up to now. Aside from Mr. Harding, who was in charge of it for a few months last Spring, the teachers have all been thoroughly incompetent. They
They have all been Englishmen, who have lived only a short time in the country, and as a rule did not know how to take care of themselves, let alone give instructions to Indians.

Sir,

I beg to inform the Department that I have just completed an inspection of the Fishing Lake reserve and while there I inspected the Day School.

1. I regret to say that there is absolutely no improvement in this school in the last two years. Instead it has gone back. I found a new teacher, an old bachelor about 60 years of age. School was being taught in one of the upstairs rooms in the farm house and there were only five small boys in attendance. They knew little or nothing. You will notice from the returns sent in from time to time that the attendance has been very unsatisfactory. This school has now been in existence for over five years and I regret to say the results obtained do not warrant the small expenditure it has occasioned.

2. The difficulty seems to get a qualified teacher, one who can influence the parents. Another trouble is the home conditions, which are very poor, and any little good that children receive at school is soon offset by the home influence.

for the quarter ending Sept. 30th, 1920.

FISHING LAKE RESERVE.

I was sent here by Commissioner Graham to re-open the Day School which had been closed for some years.

The old building previously used as a school is no longer habitable, but a new one is to be erected shortly.

The last three months I have been organizing the work here, for two months, lessons were given in a large tent kindly provided by our Agent, but I have now secured an Indian house, which can be heated, until a permanent building is ready.

On this Reserve there are 23 children of school age, the majority of them can speak no English at all, but the few I have been able to induce to attend school seem very intelligent and eager to learn, with the exception of one or two.

The Indians are anxious for their children to receive an education, and I feel confident that as soon as the children begin to speak English, the interest of the Parents will be aroused, of course it will need great patience and perseverance to conduct a school here, and I fear that for some time the attendance will be small.

I hope the Indians will eventually appreciate the school by sending their children regularly.

(SGD) A.J. LAWES.

Dear Sir:

I beg to report that the school at Fishing Lake Reserve is closed for a short while as we have a severe outbreak of measles on the reserve.

As the teacher is helping Nurse Innes while the school is closed I beg to recommend that his salary be continued as usual. When the school reopens I will advise the Department.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Ottawa, July 28, 1924.

WITH CHEQUES.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, returning the cheques which you received for salary and bonus due as teacher of the Fishing Lake Indian Day School for the June quarter last.

In reply I beg to say that all salaries due teachers of Indian day schools are now paid on a basis of ten teaching months in the year. You taught during the months of May and June, last, the school having been closed for holidays during the month of April instead of the month of July. Payment of salary and bonus due for the June quarter was, therefore, only allowed for the two months the school was open. If you teach during the present month of July payment will be made for that month.

The cheques which you forwarded are returned herewith and you should have them cashed as soon as possible.

When your return for the quarter ending September 30th is received, full payment of salary and bonus on a monthly basis for the period you teach during that time will be made.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

A. J. Lawes, Esq.,

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Allen,

In his letter of October 31st, 1934, Mr. Agent Waddy advises that the Fishing Lake Indian Day School - No. 606 - will be closed during the month of November.

This school should, therefore, be omitted from the November pay list.
December 7th, 1934.

MEMORANDUM:-

Representative of the Treasury,

In his letter of November 27th, 1934, Mr. Agent Waddy advised that the Fishing Lake Indian Day School was re-opened on December 1st, 1934.

The following entry should, therefore, appear on the December pay list:-

606 - Fishing Lake - Rev. A. J. Lawes, Kylemore, Sask. - $900.00 - $90.
Dear Sir:

I have the honor to enclose return for September quarter from the teacher of the Day School at Fishing Lake.

It will be noticed that the teacher taught school during August and asks for permission to close it in November; he did not ask for permission to keep the school open in August but I recommend that he be allowed to substitute August for November.

I inspected this place on the 3rd inst and found 23 on the register, with six boys and seven girls present, the school inspector had been at the school on the 1st inst. The place is tidy, children healthy, and a lot of vegetables put away for school use. The pupils get a noon luncheon.

They had all been promoted to new classes a few days before my visit, I will see later on if they advance any in their work.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Fishing Lake School No. 606 will be closed during November but as the school was open in August and no payment was made to the teacher for that month, the teacher should be allowed salary as usual for November.

O.K.

Nov. 12/35

M. M.
A lazy man who will not work to get food for his family and to get a good place for them to live is sure to see his children sick.

A good house should be big enough for two families, but only one family ought to live in it.

The sun is a great friend. He cannot get in unless you put a big window in your new house. Sickness is sure to visit people who live in dark houses.

Two windows are better than one. One window should be open a little all the time. You can tack a piece of cloth over the hole to keep out the wind.

An open fireplace is a good thing. When many people stay in a house the air gets bad and the fireplace carries this bad air off.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I was with the Deputy yesterday at Fishing Lake Day School and I noticed him making a note about the lack of paint on the buildings so he may be asking you about it on his return home. The following few details will get you up to date in case he asks anything.

At the school is a dwelling, one story, in good shape, painted about ten years ago. Also a small 16 x 18 building once used as a school now a warehouse. Also the school building. The places are all lumber construction.

In 1932-33 estimates an item of $60.00 was in on page 16 for painting the school but funds were not available.

The boss went with me to Gordon and Muscowequan Schools, they were in apple pie order and probably the best he has seen on his trip. Then we went to Day Star Day School and found this place ready for any sort of an inspection, dandy garden and place a treat to look at. Then to Fishing Lake where everything was also in best of shape except for need of paint. I think he went away in good humour (some spelling).

Give my best regards to Mr. Southerland. I hope he will soon be back again signing the old letters again. Not that I wish you any come down at all, I know you run the office as a good will partnership as far as employees are concerned.

Sincerely,

Dear Sir,

I am writing to ask you if a more adequate sum could be granted to feed the twenty-five school children on the reserve. At present I receive $25.00 for that purpose, and every year I have to buy food out of my own pocket to have sufficient for them. We give them an excellent dinner each day in winter, which is really the only decent meal they get. As we have no basement at the school, the food is prepared in our own kitchen by Mrs. Lawes assisted by two school girls. We think that if the children are properly fed, it will help them to keep well, and to combat TB. Good food is far more necessary to them than medicine, which is frequently wasted. We have been here over seventeen years, and not a single request for food has ever been refused at the mission for the sick and aged, as every Indian on the reserve can testify. If any food is left over after the school children have had sufficient, it is sent home for the sick aged, and young children, and is appreciated by them, as often the food...
they have is extremely poor. I have today written to Mr. Waddy and told him of my appeal to you.

I am,

Yours faithfully,

A. L. Harris

Dr. Robertson,

Regina,

Dear Sir;-

I beg to submit attached letter from Mr. Lawes re allowance for midday meals.

There is no need of my stressing the importance, I might say vital necessity, of a good midday meal for our day school children during the full school term.

The allowance of $25.00 for 26 children is totally inadequate and simply means that the children are not receiving enough food to be of any benefit or the teacher is paying for it.

I would recommend that an allowance of $8.50 per month for the full 10 months be authorized for midday meals in this school.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,

Dear Sir;-

I am in receipt of a letter from Mr. J. W. Waddy, Touchwood Agency, in which he states that the day school buildings at Fishing Lake are in need of some repairs, that nothing has been spent on them for quite a while and the teacher has been asking if we will try and assist this year.

The sitting room is very small and he would like the wall moved in 3 feet and take this space off the kitchen. This would require some plastering work afterwards and the cost, including labor and material, would be about $50.00. The lean-to back kitchen is a flat roof and this could be corrected by fixing the foundation and cutting down rafters. The place leaks as the pitch is not sufficient to let the rain run off. This would cost approximately $25.00.

The platform in the school should be rebuilt and the verandah roof repaired, the total cost of which would be approximately $35.00.

Mr. Waddy states the carpenter who does the work in this district is Mr. J.R.F. Best of Wadena.

There is an amount of $100.00 for painting the dwelling and the warehouse of the Fishing Lake Day School in the 1938-39 estimates. I would recommend that this amount be used for the purpose named above in place of painting.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

R.M. Hoey, Esq.,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo with reference to repairs that are required at the Fishing Lake Indian Day School.

The total expenditure requested in your letter is $120.00 but in preparing our appropriation for the current fiscal year it was only found possible to provide an amount of $100.00 for repairs at this school.

If the cost of the material that is required for the repairs exceeds $50.00 it will be necessary for you to forward me full details of the articles necessary in order that purchase may be made by our Purchasing Branch.

If, however, the cost of materials does not exceed $50.00 you may arrange for their purchase.

As mentioned above the total cost of materials and labour must not exceed $100.00.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

At Day Star School we only allowed $40.00 last year, and the same amount can be expended this year.

Dear Mr. Waddy:

Today we have been looking over the dwelling and storehouse at Fishing Lake Indian Reserve for which you requested to have an estimate of painting.

I may say that these buildings are badly in need of paint and are in fact gone too far. Owing to this fact we fully believe that it will take approximately 12 gallons of paint for the walls and trimmings. Of course if it would take less it would cost less. That is priced at $4.20 a gallon.

It will take approximately 25 gallons of roof paint to do the two roofs and approximately $50.00 for labor. The roof paint is $2.50 a gallon.

Now if you desire to do this we have a painter that would do the work and we would be pleased to supply the material for the same.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 3rd instant the Department will allow an amount of $40.00 for the purchase of materials required for serving a midday lunch at the Day Star Indian Day School. As our funds this year have been drastically reduced this is the total amount that can be allowed for this purpose during the academic year 1940-41. The amount should be sufficient to supply midday lunch for the winter months only.

What has been said above regarding Day Star applies also to Fishing Lake at which school an amount of $40.00 will also be allowed for the purchase of midday meal supplies during the academic year 1940-41.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

I wish to bring to your attention that the Venerable Archdeacon J. K. Irwin of the Diocese of Qu'Appelle was in the office and had quite a long conference with me in connection with the Indian work.

The Archdeacon and two of the laymen that are on the Committee visited the different points in the Diocese where our Indian schools are located and there are a lot of things that this Committee is not satisfied with. I shall take them up with you just as soon as I have the time, but the only matter that is real urgent is the kalsomining and doing a little painting at the Fishing Lake Day school. The Archdeacon informs me that this has not been touched for 8 years and is very dark and dingy. This should be kalsomined before the school opens on the 1st of October. I presume we will have to get someone at Wadena to do the work and we will also be able to buy the kalsomine and what little paint is required.

He also pointed out that the fence around the School and premises would have to be renewed because the posts were all rotten and that it would take 160 tamarack posts to do this. There is however no hurry in doing this. I expect to visit this school when there is a change of Agents at the end of the month and the fence could be left in abeyance.

I hope, however, that you will give me authority to get someone to do the kalsomining at the school and authority to purchase the kalsomine immediately. As I stated before, the other matters will be taken up as soon as we get through with the Estimates.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

Some time ago I advised you that the Indian Committee of the Diocese of Qu'Appelle, Anglican Church, interviewed me in connection with certain matters pertaining to the Indian work. The only thing that was urgent at that time was the kalsomining of the interior of the school at Fishing Lake. This I took up with you, authority has been received and the Farming Instructor at Fishing Lake has this in hand, also the posts around the school being rotten, this will be looked after by myself when I am there on the first of the month.

The next item to be dealt with is the school curriculum. They were of the opinion that more manual training should be taught at these institutions. I quite agree with them and informed them that as far as I knew Mr. Doucet had this matter in hand.

The Water supply at the Gordon school: They claimed this had never been satisfactory and they want us to send an engineer to make a thorough examination of this immediately. Since then I have been talking to Mr. Frayling, the Principal, and when I am up at Touchwood next, which will be the end of the month, I think that I can get all the information that is necessary and shall advise the Department.

The mid-day meal: This affects Fishing Lake, Day Star and Key Reserves. At the present time the policy of our Branch is to give the teacher from $40.00 to $60.00 a year to provide a mid-day meal for the children. The Indian Committee, after visiting these schools, claim this is inadequate and that instead of allowing the amounts mentioned they should allow the teacher $100.00. They were quite emphatic in this connection and gave me instances at these schools where the teacher's wife had told them that she had to provide food out of her own larder; in other words, to take food from her family to give to the Indian children when they were hungry. In this matter I agree

The Secretary,

OTTAWA, Ontario.

with them 100%
with them 100%. It is astonishing how our Branch has always been very liberal with the boarding schools but God help the Day schools. I know that I shall receive a letter advising me that there are no funds, as usual, to increase the mid-day meal, but it is more or less of a joke to ask a teacher to supply a mid-day meal for 20 to 25 children out of $40.00 a year.

Will you give this matter consideration? Because if you do not take any steps to increase this I am going to see the Fishing Lake Band if they will not vote enough money to give the children a fair mid-day meal the next time I am there.

Awaiting your reply, I remain,

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

Re: Proposals submitted by representatives of the Diocese of Qu'Appelle Anglican Church

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of September 21, in which you submit for Departmental consideration a number of proposals submitted by the Anglican Indian Committee of the Diocese of Qu'Appelle.

School Curriculum -- Indian day and residential school teachers were instructed, in a circular letter dated January 15, 1937, that at least one third of the regular instruction period should be devoted to vocational courses of study. The response to these instructions has been, on the whole, somewhat encouraging. An officer of the Department is devoting the whole of his time to the organization of these courses. A number of worth-while courses have been prepared at considerable expense and are now available for distribution to our schools. In this connection there is an old saying that it is comparatively easy to provide a horse with water, but it is somewhat difficult to compel him to drink. This saying applies to a limited number of our schools, particularly our day schools, insofar as the promotion or organization of vocational instruction is concerned.

Water Supply at Gordon's School -- It is noted that you have discussed this matter with the Principal of the school and that it is your intention to visit the school and secure additional information in the immediate future.

The Midday Meal -- You will be interested to learn that a great deal of consideration has been given during the last year to the best ways and means of providing the Indian population of the Dominion with a well-balanced diet. A nutritional survey has been made in northern Manitoba and several conferences have been held with a number of nutritional experts. Dr. Kruse, who is at this time nutritional adviser to the United States Armed Forces, visited this Department last week with the object of discussing with the acting Superintendent of Medical Services the results of certain experiments that have been undertaken amongst groups of under-nourished peoples in a number of states of the Union. The programme of the Department has in mind cannot be adopted overnight, but will, we are convinced, prove of great advantage to our Indians in the course of time. In the meantime certain initial steps have been taken. This year we purchased fifteen tons of a special biscuit prepared under the direction of the Dominion Cerealist. These biscuits have been distributed to schools in the northern sections of the Dominion. The distribution, however, has been confined to areas where vegetables have not been produced in

quantity until now. I am enclosing the formula of this biscuit for your information. It is just possible that a much wider distribution of this biscuit will be made next year. A great deal will depend upon the funds available. The cost of this biscuit is more than double the cost of biscuits purchased at any time in the past by this Department.

A number of Indian agents have, in co-operation with a great many of our day school teachers, succeeded in organizing worth-while gardens and placed the vegetables from these gardens at the disposal of the teachers for midday meals. In addition to this, a large number of root houses have been constructed during the summer months. It has been estimated by the officials that more root houses have been constructed during the present season than have been constructed at any time in the history of the Department. A great many of these root houses are designed to meet the needs of all the Indians in the band and are proving very helpful in that they ensure a constant supply of vegetables, not only for the adult Indians but for the Indians in attendance at day schools, throughout the winter months. Goat herds have also been established at a large number of our reserves. Doctors with whom this matter has been discussed are of the opinion that it is almost impossible to provide a well-balanced diet for Indians, lacking as they do an adequate milk supply. Our experience in the establishment of goat herds has been, on the whole, encouraging and satisfactory. In this connection the Department communicated with Indian Agent Davis a few weeks ago in respect to the multiplication of a number of goat herds in his agency. The receipt of this letter has not been acknowledged.

In the case of the Indian day schools referred to in the second-last paragraph of your communication, may I suggest that the teachers concerned submit to you through the agent or to the Department a list of the supplies which, in their judgment, are necessary to provide a fairly nutritious meal during the academic year. If the cost of these supplies exceeds $50.00, they will be submitted to the Purchasing Division in due course with a recommendation that the supplies requested be purchased, or that authority be granted to the agents or teachers to make such purchases. The utmost care, however, should be exercised if the purchase of tea or sugar is recommended. These purchases must be in strict conformity with existing regulations. These supplies, however, should be looked upon by the teachers and agents as temporary expedient. All our field officials should look forward to a time when the supply of vegetables and an adequate supply of milk will enable the Indians, including Indian pupils, to enjoy a diet sufficiently well balanced to encourage physical development and maintain health.

Yours truly,

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I am enclosing herewith requisition for materials and labour for repairing the interior of the day school at the Fishing Lake Reserve, also for the purchase of an oil stove at a cost of approximately $100.00, for the same school.

The present stove in use at the school is an old box stove and it is of no further use. Wood is expensive and hard to secure, consequently an oil stove would be more useful and more efficient.

When funds are available in a year or two a full sized basement should be completed under this school and a furnace installed. This would make the room much more comfortable and allow a considerably larger floor space for more desks which will be needed with the improved attendance expected with the Family Allowances.

Ottawa, July 31st, 1945.

Mr. R.S. Davis, Indian Agent, Punnichy, Sask.,

Inspector J.P.B. Ostrander has forwarded to this office your requisition of July 17th for material to repair the Fishing Lake School. The purchase of an oil stove is also recommended by the Inspector.

As you are aware a purchase over $50.00 has to be made through our Purchasing Branch and I would therefore, appreciate it if you would let me know from whom you secured the prices for the plaster board, lumber, shavings and nails.

The cost of the oil stove is estimated at $100.00. You should let me have complete information regarding the type of stove required and if possible you should state the catalogue number in order to assist our Purchasing Branch.

Philip Phelan,

Ltd., Punnichy, and estimated the cost of labor myself.

Mr. J.E. Hicks of Wadena gave me a price of $97.75 on a number 575 Duo-Thern Heater, capacity 2300.

He also has a good two burner Enterprize Heater#40, which he used in his house last winter. This is in good condition. The original cost was $130.00 but he is willing to sell for $100.00. This has a greater heating capacity than the Duo-Thern, and I think would be a better buy.

Will you please advise me by return airmail if authority is given for this work, as it should be completed before the school re-opens this fall, and workmen are hard to get.

Dear Sir:

In your letter of June 18th, 1947 you advised me that you had not received a Provincial School Inspector's Report upon the work of Dr. Mansbridge at Key Indian Day School, but that you would forward a copy of such report when it became available. To date we have not received any Inspector's Report and I am wondering if this is because no inspection has been made. We are anxious to also have copies of the Provincial School Inspector's Report upon the work of the Rev. A.J. Lawes of Fishing Lake Reserve and Mr. Robert Hick of Day Star Reserve as well as a report from your Department on the work of these gentlemen.

We would like to know if it is possible for the Department of Indian Affairs to remunerate our Day School Teachers for the janitor work they have to do at their schools, also for providing the mid-day meals for the children. I may say that in the white schools of our Province any teacher who is required to do janitor work receives an allowance for doing so, and it is felt that this should also apply to the teachers in Indian Day Schools.

I will be pleased to hear from you regarding these matters, especially the first mentioned as if it is considered necessary that we should replace any of our teachers, it is advisable to soon advertise for others.

J.P.B. Ostreider, Esq., Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies, Regina, Sask.

Re your letter #1346-300-IIA July 12, 1948
Fishing Lake Day School

On sheet #3 Schools, Estimates 1948-49, will be found items for attention to school, digging basement, labour cement work, painting of school and residence, totalling $2500.00. Attached hereto is form #7 listing materials and labour to build a 6' X 22' extension to the present building, enlarge the school room by removing the cloak room partitions, insulating the building, digging basement, construction of a cement basement, removing and rebuilding chimney, and moving the building onto the new basement.

Mr. R.L. Brooks of Wadena has offered to supply all labour in this connection including shavings for insulation at a cost of $2200.00, it being understood that if the walls of the building have not been constructed with headers the cost of insulation will be $90.00 less than the price quoted on Form #7, namely $220.00.

Mr. Ed Ward of Wadena offered to do this work less the moving of the building on to the new site for the sum of $2700.00. An offer was also made by Mr. F.A. Holmman, Wadena, to move the building from the present site onto the basement for the sum of $300.00.

The offer submitted by R.L. Brooks is reasonable and I would recommend that favourable consideration be given to this offer.

Also attached hereto is Form #7 listing the materials and labour required for exterior and interior decorating of the school house, teacher's residence, storehouse, and outside toilets. The labour includes two coats of outside painting, tightening all nails, and minor repair work, also two coats of paint to the interior of the teacherage and school amounting to $709.50. Mr. Gordon W. Russell, Wadena has offered to do this work for the sum of $300.00, spray and brush to be used. Messrs. Fred H. and Max Olson have offered to do it for the sum of $325.00, all work to be done by brush. It is not considered advisable to do a paint job on the school house until it has been enlarged and moved onto the basement. Due to the moving of the building it might result in damage to the plastered ceiling and inside walls and could result in making an unnecessary expenditure.

I would recommend that the school be moved this year if at all possible even though it may result in having the class rooms closed for the month of September. It is estimated that about seven weeks will be required to move the school and put it in shape for use.

In the event this work is done a furnace will be required which will mean an added expenditure of approximately $370.00

I recommend that consideration be given to have the painting done by brush. I understand that brush work is proving more satisfactory than spray work.

Prince Albert, Sask.
August 4, 1913.

The Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs.

Dear Sir,-

I address this letter to you as instructed, and I ask your assistance and advice towards obtaining my request. It is a matter of such importance that I would ask you to bring it before the Minister of Indian Affairs at the earliest possible opportunity, and also to see that the matter is not dropped after it has been opened up.

My work and the work of my missionaries among our Indians gives us opportunity of learning their state, their needs, their desires, in a way that you will rarely learn from your Indian agents and Instructors. I beg therefore, to press upon your Department the pressing need of day schools as follows: (among others perhaps not mentioned) I am sure the Indian Department knows of the non-existence of such schools and of the desire of the Indians to have them, and perhaps the I.D. has been considering the matter. But I would press for the building and maintaining of these schools almost immediately.

(1) The Indians are retrograding and suffering for the lack (2) It does not seem in accordance with "Treaty" to leave them without (3) They desire and ask for them. I cannot be sure of correct names, but I think what I write is sufficient to point them out correctly.

1.- Frog Lake, Nos. 121 and 122, but especially Ooncepowhao (121) We have worked here for years but there has been no school. They sent a few children to Onion Lake boarding school. They will no longer do so as they want the day school system. I have sent a Cree teacher there, Ch. Quinaly, an intelligent, educated man (half breed I think)

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6284, file 607-1, part 1)
to open school as best he can in his own house, or in the Indian houses. I have to build a house for him. This is not fair to the Church funds which are not meant for schools. I beg to apply (1) for his salary, (2) for purchase of the residence for him, (3) for a school to be built for him (4) for an improved day school to be maintained.

Dear Mr. Scott:

You may remember that a long time ago I applied for a grant from the I.D. for a teacher at Frog Lake. I think the reply was that though the I.D. was not prepared to start in the usual way, that if I would go ahead and put a teacher there, the I.D. would be ready to receive a report of the work done, and then to consider the matter of payment. I beg to report briefly what has been done. Mr. Charles Quinney began teaching school about the first of July last. He had to build his own house and then gather the children together and start teaching with such little outfit as we were able to give him. I give you the following notes from a report I have received from our clergyman there.

(1) We have built two shacks each 16x16.
(2) There are sixteen children of school age on the reserve.
(3) The attendance was small because most of the children are barely of school age and are scattered over the reserve. The few that go have attended regularly and made good progress.
(4) Inspector Chisholm visited the teacher, but not during school hours, looked at the work on the slates, and expressed satisfaction with what he saw. He promised to recommend the I.D. to help in the work.
(5) If the I.D. takes up the work regularly, it would be advisable by next winter to have arrangements made for driving the children to school.
(6) The Indians desire a school on the reserve as they do not wish to send their children to the boarding schools at Onion Lake.

Charles Quinney has received from us about $250 for the twelve months work. It is not sufficient. He has had to scrape along in the best way he could, and we have helped him in other little ways. Besides that there is the money that we have spent on the two shacks for his house and the school. I am not sure what this amounts to, but my point is this, that we have done this work for the I.D. in order to show them that the work was worth while and possible. We cannot afford to do this and I think that the I.D. should repay us our outlay on salary and houses, and make definite arrangements to pay the teacher direct from this out. I think that if you write to Mr. Sibbald, your agent there, he will endorse what I have said. There are some Roman Catholics there, and the new chief is one, and they may make a move to have the school entrusted to them, but we are the first in the field, we have begun the education of the children, and I think we have the majority of the Indians. These things ought to be in our favour. Will you do what you can in this matter? First to repay us what we are out of pocket and cannot afford to donate, and second to have the school put on the usual footing, that is to build and equip and to furnish the salary. Whatever school material there is now, either the teacher or the Church provided at their own
expense. There should be a proper schoolhouse, also a house for the teacher, with at least two rooms for his family and another room for the mid-day meal. I do not ask an expensive building, only sufficient to carry on the work.

If this request and report is not sufficiently definite, will you tell me just what you want, and will you communicate with Mr. Sibbald?

Yours faithfully,

Dear Mr. Scott,

I would plead for what seems to me only justice & honesty to a very deserving servant as follows, & I would ask you to do your best to get the J.D. to make whatever liberal allowance they can.

You will remember that Charles Lucieney taught school at Frog Lake near Qu'Appelle Lake for a year or more partly at our expense partly at his own. Then the J.D. recognized the value of his work, & the need of a school there, & granted him a small salary ($300, I think). I understand (it may have been my mistake) that the J.D. also considered the need of a school-building, & would take it up with the Agent at Qu'Appelle Lake. However, this is what I learn now.

In July 1913, he built two shacks at his own expense, one to live in, & the other for a class-room. In spring of 1914 he rented a house that was more central for the children, paying the rent out of his meagre salary. He also added a lean-to to the house, & has taught there ever since. He has been out of pocket for (1) two shacks (2) a lean-to & (3) rent.

The Indians were so pleased with the progress of their children that they agreed to take out logs for a school, & the Chief &
council gave a site for it as for teacher's house. Mr. Sibbald, the agent, promised to write to the Dept. to ask what help would be given towards the building. Nothing has been heard from him about it. Lumley started to build a house for himself on the given site with the help of the Indians, but the Agent said he could not do so without the permission of the Dept., so he stopped, discouraged.

Now here is a case where Teacher, pupils, & Indians are all willing & eager to do their best & more than their share. The work has been commenced. The teacher is studying with the utmost desire to become more proficient. The school & the house are both needed by August. I would ask (1) that a generous recompense be paid to Lumley for the use of his buildings for two years past; (2) that the grant of the site by Chief & Council be approved; (3) that the willingness of the people be met half-way by a suitable grant towards the expense of building a school or a small residence, & that Mr. Sibbald be instructed to pay Mr. Lumley for the past, & to meet the Indians' desire, & to help in the building without delay.

With best regards to yourself,

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of 15th inst. No. 443013/1 informing me that His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan was being informed that the Department does not feel justified in keeping the Frog Lake school open in view of the poor attendance recorded.

In reply I beg to say that I regret very much that the Department desires to close this school. I hope that my reference in any respect to only one being present on Oct 21st has not led the Department to its decision.

I would explain that at the time mentioned nearly all the families were absent from the reserve. I was on my return journey from the north and on my way going north on the 11th I had spoken to the Indians about the good wages to be earned among the settlers and with the thirsting spirits moving about the country and found on my return that a number of them had moved out to look for work on my advice and had taken their families with them. It is true the attendance is poor and it is only recently I have spoken with the...
Indians and with the teacher about it. The general impression is that if a building could be built in a more central position there would be better attendance. There are several children at the north end of the lake that would attend if the school was nearer them and it was suggested that I would try to get a building more convenient. The Indians know had a building in their mind which it was probable I could get a house belonging to Joseph Delorme which he has not been living in for some months. However at the time did not encourage the idea telling them that I expected that when the war was over and times grew better the Department would consider the advisability of building a proper school which would be placed in the most advantageous position. I did not at the time however anticipate that the Department proposed closing the school. The teacher said if he could still have the use of the house that he is now living in which costs the Dept $14.50 per month, that he would be willing to travel between the two places morning and evening distances of about 14 miles if the Joseph Delorme house could be purchased. I don't know if he is going to live in it this winter but if he is not I think the house could be rented at about $5.00 per month.
Outside Mr. Chattingup duties as a school teacher he interests himself in many ways in the welfare of the Indians. He attends their meetings and gives them good advice; the Indians in return respect him & have come to look to him for advice. He is at times of considerable help to me and if he is moved I would miss him very much. One thing in particular I would mention about him he was helpful in stopping the Indians from having a third dance last June which they were very persistent in trying to hold. Should the Department entertain the idea of trying how the school would succeed by holding it in Delore house I would suggest doing so rather than recommencing the closing of the school altogether.

I hope the Department will accept this letter in the spirit in which it is meant & reconsider its decision in reference to the school.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Scott,

I received your letter lately (of Oct. 16th., No. 445013/1) from your department, saying that in consequence of the lack of pupils the Frog Lake School would be closed after Dec. 31st. I was much distressed as I knew that the teacher was doing faithful work, & it is the only Day School in that large Indian district, while the Onion Lake Boarding School is already as full as the I.D. grant allows.

I have just received a letter from Rev. E. Ahenakew, my missionary there, lamenting the proposal to close the school. He says that Mr. Sibbald, Indian Agent strongly recommends that it be kept open because (1) It is doing good work, (2) the teacher, Charles Quinney has a good influence on the Indians. Mr. Sibbald says that the fault of the lack of attendance in summer is largely his own, that he advised the Indians to go across the river & help the farmers with the harvest. They will be more at the Reserve now. I hope therefore that you will reconsider the closing of the school, & be guided by Mr. Sibbald's recommendation to keep it open.

I beg to remain yours faithfully,

MEMORANDUM:

MR. SCOTT.

Regarding the application of H. Bowtell of Frog Lake, addressed to W. J. Blair, M.P., for an increase in salary to Charles Quinney, Teacher, Indian Day School, Frog Lake, I beg to say that this school was first opened on September 1st, 1914, and Mr. Quinney was appointed teacher at a salary of $300.00 per annum. During the past three years he has also received bonus at the rate of $150.00 per annum.

Previous to teaching in this school, Mr. Quinney taught five or six years in Indian Schools.

He has no professional qualifications, having only passed the high school entrance for the Province of Saskatchewan.

There is an enrollment of 23 pupils, with an average attendance of only seven.

The late Inspector Crombie, who made the last inspection of this school, remarks regarding the work "he appears only to be able to get his pupils to a certain point, which does not extend beyond elementary subjects. The discipline is good". The pupils are mostly in the first and second standard.

Mr. Quinney is an Indian, and received his education in Emmanuel College, Prince Albert, which was one of our boarding schools.

Except for the bonus, Mr. Quinney has had no increase in salary since he began work at this school, and in view of his long service, which meets the requirements at this school, we might allow him an increase of $100.00 from the first of the present fiscal year.

Memorandum:

HONOURABLE THOMAS G. MURPHY

With reference to your memorandum of the 4th instant, regarding Mrs. Peterson, wife of the teacher of the Frog Lake Indian Day School, I submit the following information:

Mr. Peterson, teacher of the Indian Day School at Frog Lake, was appointed in January, 1924, at a salary of $95 a teaching month and a grant of $50 a year as dispenser of medicines. In February, 1928, the Indian agent reported that Mrs. Peterson had been a great help to the Indian women of the Band and suggested that she be allowed remuneration for her services at the rate of $150 a year. This is due to the fact that a large percentage of the Indians obtain their livelihood from hunting and trapping, working out for white settlers scrubbing land, and occupations which take them away from their Reserve. As they have no facilities for leaving their children at the school, they have to take them along and consequently the attendance at the school suffers. Until such time as these Indians take up farming and stock raising seriously as a source of livelihood, it cannot be expected that the attendance at the day school will be satisfactory.

Your obedient servant,

W. Murison,

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your 115-4-1, of the 13th instant, with reference to Inspector Gibault's report on the Frog Lake Indian Day School. The Department's comment has been fully noted.

Mr. Peterson, the teacher, and I have been doing all we can to make the school justify its existence but have only partially succeeded. In order to get a better attendance we have been using moral suasion with the parents and in some instances compulsion, but we find it difficult to compete with our Residential Schools where they have so much more to offer. Twenty-four children from this reserve are in residence at the Onion Lake Boarding School - Four at the C. of E., and twenty at the R. C., while the enrolment at the Day School on the reserve is but twelve. The children in the Residential Schools are properly clothed and well nourished and do not have to expose themselves in severe weather to get to their class rooms, whereas the average child attending the Day School is insufficiently clad, is exposed to all kinds of weather getting to and from school, which in many instances is a considerable distance, and gets one mid-day meal for five months only. The Indians have a decided preference for the Day School, and I like it because I think it serves their requirements better than any other, but, in my opinion, it will never be the success it should be unless put on a better and more generous basis. I would respectfully recommend that the mid-day meal be made continuous throughout the teaching year, and that each pupil enrolled be given a complete outfit of suitable clothing, consisting of a tweed suit, overcoat, cap, mitts, boots or mocassins, two pairs of socks or stockings, and two shirts and two suits of underwear. In addition, the matter of transportation to and from school for the winter months should be considered. We have four Indian Day Schools in the Agency with a total enrolment of seventy, distributed as follows: Frog Lake 12, Long Lake 18, Island Lake 14, and Waskesiu's 26. The probable cost of clothing would depend largely on the quality, but a per capita allowance of approximately $15.00 should procure a suitable equipment. The cost of the mid-day meal for an additional five months would just be double the amount expended for that purpose at present, and transportation for the four winter months would be approximately $10.00 per month for each school.

The drafting of children for the Residential Schools
Schools from reserves where there are Day Schools should cease excepting under special circumstances, where a child is orphaned or living too remote from a Day School to attend regularly.

I fully realize that if these recommendations are put into effect they will result in a substantial increase in the cost of operating Indian Day Schools, but I feel sure that the results will justify the expenditure, and the total cost of educating a child in the Day School would still be considerably less than one half the amount required for maintenance in the Residential School, and it is my considered opinion that the ex-pupil from a good Day School is just as well or perhaps better equipped to take up his position in the reserve as his brother from the Residential School.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

J. T. Hill,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 25th ultimo, with reference to the Frog Lake Indian Day School.

If clothing was furnished to all pupils of Indian day schools in the manner you suggest it is doubtful if $15 a year would be sufficient. At any rate, if such action was favourable considered, it would be a matter of relief and not an expenditure from the Appropriation for Indian Education.

It is also doubtful if transportation could be arranged at $10 a month. In some other places where transportation has been provided the cost has been much higher. In many cases it has been found difficult to secure the children, as those residing at some distance from the school did not arise early enough in the morning to permit the driver to reach the school for nine o'clock.

The Department agrees with you that Indian parents residing on a reserve where a day school is located, and who are in a position to support their children, should not be allowed to send their children to a residential school. This is a matter, however, that would have to be decided by yourself in co-operation with the principals of the residential schools who recruit on those reserves where Indian day schools are located. Orphan or neglected children living on such reserves should receive the preference at residential schools.

Dear Mr. Robertson:

At a Convention of the Independent Political Association of Alexandra held at Marwayne I was nominated a candidate to contest the next Provincial Election. I accepted this nomination somewhat reluctantly, knowing that it would interfere with my duties here on the Reserve, and that I would probably be forced to resign.

I never sought this nomination nor did any campaigning on my behalf; but the majority of the 63 delegates present decided it was up to me to stand and having been a resident of this district for 28 years and interested in the welfare and good government of this province I could not very well refuse.

The Association I now represent is comprised of the Liberal and Conservative parties and others interested in the defeat of the Social Credit Govt. I feel that with an Independent Govt. in power at Edmonton much more assistance and cooperation could be given the Federal Govt. in the prosecution of the war and other matters than is possible under the present regime.

The Provincial Election will no doubt
held this spring or early summer, and it will then be necessary for me to give my whole time to the campaign and would need leave of absence from my duties. The wife will of course be home to carry on with the Homemakers' Club etc but would necessitate another teacher taking my place in the school.

I have talked this matter over with Dr. Hill and he suggests that possibly I could engage a teacher to act for me while I take away. Should I be defeated in the election my wish is of course to continue here as I have no other home or job to go to. If successful other arrangements would have to be made.

I am leaving this matter entirely up to you Mr. Robertson to decide if you wish that I resign I will of course have to do so.

Trusting to hear from you soon on this matter and in the meantime I am carrying on as usual.

Yours Truly,

A.E. Peterson

P.S. If this request for leave of absence is granted I would like it to start April 1st. A.E.P.
Regina, January 19, 1940.

Dear Sir:

Re: Frog Lake School, Onion Lake Agency.

I am attaching a letter from Mr. A. E. Peterson, Teacher at the above referred to school. You will note from this letter that Mr. Peterson has accepted nomination to contest that seat in the next Provincial election; that his nomination would not interfere with his work before the first of April, at which time he would like to get leave of absence and engage another teacher to take his place; that should he be defeated, he would like to return to the school and carry on, but if elected would resign.

As you are aware, we have no Farming Instructor or other representative on the Frog Lake Reserve with the exception of the School Teacher. Up until last spring I was very much dissatisfied with conditions on that Reserve. The school attendance was very poor and practically nothing was being done in the way of gardening or agriculture. Last spring I took this matter up with the Agent and Mr. Peterson and got Mr. Peterson to start a Community Garden and do some outside work in encouraging the Indians to do a little more in agriculture, also got Mrs. Peterson to start a Homemakers' Club.

The Community Garden went over very well but was not located as well as it might have been and the results were not what we expected. They have, however, another piece of land prepared for next season. The Homemakers' Club has gone over well. The women are taking a great interest and the Indians have put up a building for the use of the Club. The Agent, Dr. Hill, advises that the school attendance has also improved. They have now an enrolment of 23 and there were...........

The Secretary,

there were 17 present at his last visit. He also states that the children are all outfitted with good suits and dresses made by the Homemakers' Club and that Mrs. Peterson is doing excellent work.

This is a case where we have a Reserve with some of the best agricultural land in the Agency; where we have Indians who are doing much less in agriculture than they were a number of years ago. The Indians themselves express the desire to take up agriculture, but the amount of agriculture being done at the present time would not warrant the appointment of a Farming Instructor. It is a case where I am satisfied a Teacher in the dual position of Teacher and Overseer could carry on educational work and at the same time, within the next two or three years, get the Indians started in agriculture sufficiently to warrant the employment of an Instructor, and it is the only way that I can see in which we can get these people started.

I think I am safe in saying that this last year, through Mr. Peterson's outside work and the Homemakers' Club, we have done more to bring these people along than had been done in the previous five years. It is unfortunate that Peterson is asking leave on the 1st of April, as that means he would be away at the very time he is most needed to carry on the outside work, Community Gardening, etc. While I feel that the interests of both the Indians and the Department demand, in a case of this kind, that the Teacher act in a dual capacity, and under those conditions I would hesitate to recommend that Mr. Peterson be given leave, in view of the intimation contained in one of your recent letters that the Department objects to our Teachers being used for anything but classroom work, I am of the opinion that his wish could be granted, as no doubt he could secure a teacher who would carry on the classroom work efficiently during his absence, and the Community Garden and Homemakers' work could be abandoned, as would in any case have to be done if our teachers are to be used exclusively for classroom work.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 19th instant and also a letter received by you from Mr. A. E. Peterson, teacher at the above noted school, enclosed therewith. May I refer you to departmental letter dated January 16, 1939, and particularly to clauses (a), (b), and (c) in the last paragraph of that communication. There is nothing on file here to indicate that the Department has received at any time a reply to that letter.

Section 55 of the Civil Service Act reads as follows:

"No deputy head, officer, clerk or employee in the civil service shall be debarred from voting at any Dominion or provincial election if, under the law governing the said election, he has the right to vote; but no such deputy head, officer, clerk or employee shall engage in partisan work in connection with any such election, or contribute, receive or in any way deal with any money for any party funds.

"Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be dismissed from the civil service. 1918, c 12, s. 32."

In view of this statutory provision, Civil Servants are prohibited from taking an active part in political campaigns or in the promotion of political organizations. It would appear, therefore, that when Mr. Peterson is officially nominated as candidate for the Provincial Legislature he will be subject to dismissal by this Department. I should state perhaps quite frankly that the officials here have never had before them a case exactly similar to the one presented to us in your letter. It might be argued that distinction should be drawn between Provincial and Dominion politics. I am personally of the opinion, however, that Mr. Peterson by becoming a candidate, regardless of whether he was elected or defeated, would place himself in a very unenviable position. This branch, as you know, works in very close cooperation -

Dr. Thomas Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Regina, Sask.
co-operation with the provincial departments of Education. Provincial public school inspectors inspect all Indian schools in the Dominion, with the exception of Indian schools in the provinces of British Columbia and New Brunswick. The Premier of the province of Alberta is also Minister of Education and the school inspectors work under his direction. I need not pursue this course of reasoning; you can readily reach your own conclusions. Mr. Peterson, in my humble judgment, should either continue as teacher at the Frog Lake school or resign almost at once. Any recommendation from you, after you have discussed the matter with the church authorities, in respect to the man that should take his place, will be acceptable to the Department.

Yours truly,
