Extract from report of R. Racette, following his inspection of the FROG LAKE Indian Day School, dated June 25, 1943.

In the absence of Mr. Hunt, who has been bedridden for the last month, Mrs. Hunt is replacing him and will do so until the end of this term. My inspection was also made difficult by the non-attendance of so many pupils who are reported to be helping their parents. Under the circumstances, I have examined the written work of these six pupils and have observed a few lessons in reading, oral language and number work. It is my intention to visit this school again next October.

My examination of the school register reveals the fact that during the first Quarter of this year only six pupils out of 28 enrolled attended 50% of the days the school operated and about ten reached this percentage during the quarter expiring in March. As a result of this poor attendance and the lack of suitable classroom material the progress of these Indian children is very slow. They speak in mere whispers, are too often daydreaming. I consider that until authorities have adopted a special definite curriculum for the Indian schools, have equipped the classrooms with necessary primary material and above all have enforced compulsory attendance, the results will remain negligible in academic accomplishments. Mrs. Hunt reports that the pupils have cp-operated lately in the making of a garden. The girls also take sewing lessons with the adults.
Ottawa, July 14, 1943.

Mr. Donald H. Cameron, Indian Agent, Onion Lake, Sask.

I have recently received the report of Inspector Racette regarding his inspection of the Frog Lake Indian Day School on June 25th. Apparently, Mr. Hunt was still absent from the school, although I was under the impression, from your letter of May 17, that he would resume duties about May 24. Please let me know his present condition and advise if he will be able to re-open the school on September first.

In reporting on the school, the Inspector writes in part as follows:

"My examination of the school register reveals the fact that during the first quarter of this year only 8 pupils out of 28 enrolled attended 50% of the days the school operated and about 10 reached this percentage during the quarter ending March 31."

This attendance is very unsatisfactory and suggests that it might be as well to close the school. I would appreciate receiving your comments immediately and if you consider the school should remain open, you should state what steps will be taken to secure a larger and more regular attendance.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
REPORT ON FROG LAKE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

I wish to inform you that while on the Frog Lake Reserve the week before last I visited Mr. and Mrs. O.R. Hunt and had quite a chat with them. Mr. Hunt is the teacher of the Day School on this Reserve and Mrs. Hunt does a great deal to assist him.

This couple, I believe, are doing splendid work on this reservation. Mr. Hunt, as you know, has been ill lately but he was progressing favourably at the time of my visit so I think he will be in shape to open the school on September 1st. However, Dr. Miller of Elk Point was going to Frog Lake to examine him again the week following my visit.

Mid-Day Meal

I was advised by Mr. Hunt that there are from fifteen to twenty-two children attending this school and at the present time they are receiving only $36.00 a year to supply the mid-day meal for these children. He further informed me they often have to take food from their own supply to feed the children. I asked him how much money he required and he stated $10.00 a month. This would be about right. However, we compromised and I said for the present I would recommend $75.00 for the school year; therefore I would ask that this amount be available for the school.

Gardens

As you are probably aware, this band of Indians are very backward and they are still more or less in the primitive state. Mr. and Mrs. Hunt are the first people to come to Frog Lake who are really interested in the work and doing their best not only in the way of teaching but on the reserve in general where they more or less act as farming instructors. There are eighteen gardens on the reserve this year and this is entirely due to their efforts. There is also a community garden at the school which belongs to the Indian women who are members of the Homemakers' Club there. During my visit they were canning the vegetables. I noted in my general report on this Agency that some of the women who would not help with the garden in the Spring were now anxious to get in on the vegetables. Probably next Spring they will show more interest in the Homemakers' club garden.

Homemakers' Club — They have a good Homemakers' club....
They have a good Homemakers' Club on this reserve and a great deal of the military clothing we send them is made into clothing for the children at the school, etc. Personally I cannot speak too highly of the work Mr. and Mrs. Hunt are doing. Besides this, they are good Canadians raised in the Melfort district where their people farm. Mr. Hunt is thirty-seven years of age and Mrs. Hunt is probably around thirty-five. They have four children of their own who attend a white school just outside of the reserve. Mr. and Mrs. Hunt like their work and are very much interested in it. These are the kind of people we want to encourage and make it worth their while to stay in this work.

Mr. and Mrs. Hunt asked for a cow and if the cow is supplied they will use the milk for the children attending the school and give whatever is over to anyone who is sick on the reserve. You, of course, will realize that just at the present time cows are cows and we will probably have to pay $125.00 for one. Then, of course, there is the feed for the winter. Mr. Hunt has a stable so there will be no extra expense for this and the cow will cost around $150.00.

The well at the school needs cleaning out but this will not be a costly job. A tank is required and also some boards for earstroughing but I have asked the Agent to send in a requisition for this so our Branch will receive that later.

As I mentioned above in this report, Mr. and Mrs. Hunt are doing splendid work but if we are going to keep them at Frog Lake we must encourage them and should the former teacher, Mr. Peterson, who I presume is away on military leave although I have no record to this effect here, want to get back into the Department after the War I do not think he should be sent back to Frog Lake. I am just giving you this as a hint.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,

Ottawa, April 14, 1924.

WITH CHEQUES.

Sir,-

The March quarter return of the Frog Lake Indian Day School has been received.

As you are aware, the Department agreed some time ago to allow Mrs. Quinney salary until a new teacher was appointed for this school.

It is noted that Mr. Peterson began duties February 25th, last, and he is being allowed salary, therefore, for one week in February and the month of March at the rate of $800.00 per annum. The amount, therefore, due him is $100.00.

We are allowing Mrs. Quinney payment for the month of January and three weeks in February at the rate of $400.00 per annum. The amount, therefore, due her is $700.00.

The bonus is being paid for the same period; the amount due being $26.25 for Mrs. Quinney and $18.75 for Mr. Peterson. The bonus cheques are enclosed herewith and you should hand them to the respective parties.

The cheques for the salaries will be forwarded to you under separate cover.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,

Sir,

I have your letter of the 7th instant, relative to the request of Mr. A. E. Peterson, teacher of the Frog Lake Indian Day School, that an increased remuneration be allowed for the extra services being performed by Mrs. Peterson and himself.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that when I was last at Roy Lake Reserve I called at the little day school that has recently been opened there by the C.E. mission at Onion Lake with Mr. Chas. Kerney as teacher.

You are aware that this school is being held in a house belonging to one of the Indians and that the intention is not to build a school-house until it is seen how the undertaking, in its present form, succeeds.

It was a cold windy day when I called at the school, there were only two children present besides two of the teacher's own children. The only school material in the place was a few broken desks and a primus that was scarcely kept the stove almost went up, there was also a small blackboard that would serve the purpose fairly well but there was no chalks. I told Mr. Kerney to send me a requisition for such things as he required and I hope enclosed the list received from him.

I would recommend that they be authorized to purchase such of these articles as the Department is not in the habit of sending by express or otherwise, with the exception of the blackboards, desks &c., as there are some old desks at the C.E. Boarding school here which I think can be made good enough to serve the purpose at Roy Lake, I do not think it would be advisable to buy new desks until it is decided to
build a regular school house, the draft I can supply from agency stock. With regard to teachers I would ask that enough be sent for at least 10 pupils.

The reason of these only being two little children at the school on the occasion of my visit was the cold weather. This was the number there on the roll, two of these two boys did come from the school and in order to help as much as possible the teacher has been helping them with his own family giving them board and lodging from Monday morning until Friday evening and he knows of two children more that could attend on same conditions. The teacher asked that he may be allowed some flour, bacon and tea for these children and he will be quite willing to keep. I told him that no doubt that could be arranged. I would therefore ask to be authorized to allow him 30 lbs. flour & 1 lb. bacon & 1 lb. tea per head per month. This arrangement would suit the conditions and secure a more regular attendance. The engaging an Indians to sign round and gather the children to the school and take them home again.

I enclose the teacher's return for the past quarter in which he was teaching in the present house, hence the reason for the days missed and days absent do not give the total of the number of school days.

Yours obedient servant,

W. Sibbald

Sir,

With reference to the temporary Day School at Frog Lake reserve, I beg to report as follows:

During one of my recent visits to the reserve, the Indians informed me that they had selected a site for a Day School, and were cutting logs with a view to having a permanent school built.

I told them that when the Department had settled upon establishing a permanent school, a properly planned building would be erected, which would probably be a frame one, but that it was not likely that it would be built in the near future; but that as they had commenced to cut the logs they could continue the work and haul them to the site, and that perhaps the Department would render them some assistance in putting up a building that would be more suitable for a schoolhouse than the one at present in use, but that even it would only be temporary.

The present building is a leanto connected with a good Indian house, which the teacher, Charles Quinney, has rented from Daniel Stanley, one of the Frog Lake Indians. This leanto serves the purpose just at present, but, as Stanley will require it next fall, a temporary building could be put up in the meantime, out of the logs the Indians are providing. There are only eight children on the roll and the attendance has not been...
been very regular, so that I do not think that there is yet sufficient encouragement to induce the Department to incur the expense of establishing an improved Day School. However; the encouragement is certainly sufficient to warrant a continuation of the present system, and I would like to know if the Department would be willing to defray the expense of completing a log building, i.e. roof, floor, windows, doors, etc., if the Indians put up the walls voluntarily. I estimate that the cost of completing the building would be about $250.00.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

Sir,

I have the honour to report that the Rev. E. Ahenakew, Church of England Missionary at this Agency, came to see me this morning with reference to the Frog Lake Indian Day School, which is conducted under the auspices of the Church of England.

I should explain that a new log church is being erected by Mr. Ahenakew on the Frog Lake Indian reserve, and is nearly completed. The object of Mr. Ahenakew's visit to me was to point out that the building now used as a Day School at Frog Lake is not large enough to accommodate all the pupils now attending and to offer the use of the new church for that purpose.

The size of the present school building is about 18'x18'. The size of the new church is about 20'x24'. This latter, however, can easily be enlarged by lengthening the building with logs to 32'x24'. This could be done for about $100.00, which amount I placed in estimates to paint and repair the present schoolhouse; this amount could be diverted to the new project. In addition to this it would be necessary to build two outhouses at a cost of about $15.00 each, and also to dig and drive a well, which could be done at a cost of about $40.00. We have a pump and piping on hand which was purchased for the present school but not yet installed; this could be used for the new well if necessary.

If the present good attendance at the Day School continues it will be necessary to provide more accommodation. The average for last quarter was 15.19, and on the occasion of one of my visits to the school 22 pupils were present.

I feel that the history of the attendance at this school during the past few years has not been such as to justify me in recommending a change to larger quarters with any great degree of enthusiasm, but as the change would not cause the Department any great expense, and as also I believe the site of the new church to be a better one for the school children than the present one, I would recommend that the offer of Rev. I have your No. 309-11A of the 26th ultimo, furnishing an estimate of the cost of the painting of the interior and exterior of the Frog Lake Indian Day School, also the cost of providing better lighting facilities.

Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
Sir:

I beg to inform you that I am in receipt of a letter from Indian Agent, Lang Turner, in which he informs me that the present Anglican Day School on the Frog Lake Reserve is too small to accommodate the number of pupils attending. The last quarter shows an average attendance of 15.19.

Mr. Turner informs me that the missionary Mr. Ahenakew, is erecting a church on this reserve and has offered to use it as a school. The church that is being erected is 20' x 24'. He is willing however, to extend this building to 32'x24' if he can get a grant of $100 from the Department. In looking over the estimates it is noted that $100.00 was asked for for repairs to the school, and it seems to me that a grant of $100.00 to Mr. Ahenakew to apply on his combination church and school would be much better than to spend this amount on the present school building.

If this authority is granted a further amount of $30 will be needed for closets, and $40 for the cribbing of a well. It is pointed out that they have a good pump.

I would be glad to have your authority to act in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

W. W. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

I have the honour to enclose herewith Voucher No. 136, amounting to $195.85 in my favour, for cash expended on addition and repairs to the Anglican church building on the Frog Lake reserve, to make it suitable for use as an Indian Day School; and to offer the following explanations.

On October 22nd, I accompanied the Rev. E. Ahenakew, Indian Missionary, to the Frog Lake reserve, taking with me Mr. E. Rotherham, a handy man of this district, who was to work as carpenter and to supervise the alterations to the church building. Mr. Ahenakew stayed with Mr. Rotherham for ten days and worked at the building himself; he also hired some Indians to work at it, paying them from funds which he had received from the church authorities for that purpose. Mr. Ahenakew then left this Agency to visit Battleford reserves, but before leaving he handed over to me the balance of the money he had on hand to be expended on the building, which amounted to $25.85. This amount, together with that of a countable cheque No. 3735 for $170.00, a total of $195.85, is accounted for in the attached voucher. These added amounts proved insufficient to complete the work and Voucher No. 137 for $20.00, in favour of Mr. A. Peterson, the school teacher, is also enclosed.

The building has been converted into a fine roomy school and is now being used as such. I visited this building on November 28th, and although 20 pupils were then present the schoolroom could hold many more. The present floor space is 20 by 30 feet. It will be necessary to purchase blinds for the windows; these, however, are inexpensive and will be purchased by me on my next visit to Lloydminster, our nearest town.

In perusing the Voucher it will be noticed that some of the items in Rahall, Bros. account are provisions. These were purchased by Rev. E. Ahenakew for Indians employed at work on the school.

I have the honour to be

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

Extract from Inspector's Report on the Frog Lake School, May 7, 1925.

The local church, property of the Church of England, is used as a school. This building is larger and much better lighted than that previously used. Four windows east and two west supply light. The ventilation is good. The building will need extra repairs to make it suitable for winter use.

The well is in need of attention.

The general tone of this school has been raised appreciably. A garden is being prepared which will give the teacher some opportunity of teaching agriculture in a practical way. If possible extra teaching along the lines of manual arts for boys and household science for girls should be provided.

A house some ten yards from the school could after considerable repair be taken over by the teacher as a residence from which point the work of the school could be better supervised and the services of Mrs. Peterson could be enlisted in the teaching of the elements of domestic science and of sewing to the girls attending. The preparation of the lunch could then also be prepared outside of the school room an obvious drawback at present.

Inspector Crispie
Ottawa, June 15th, 1925.

Sir:

Public School Inspector Crispo, in a report on his inspection of the Frog Lake Indian Day School, draws attention to the condition of the well, which he states is in need of attention. Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report in connection with a visit which I made to the schools in the Onion Lake Agency:

FROG LAKE DAY SCHOOL.

I visited this school on Sept. 6th. Since my last visit a teacher's residence has been built in close proximity to the school and this increases his efficiency as before this building was provided the teacher had to drive several miles morning and evening to and from the school. There were present 5 girls and 2 boys out of an enrolment of 20 pupils. The attendance at this school is rather intermittent owing to the parents living a nomadic life through hunting, trapping and working out for settlers being their chief source of livelihood. The pupils in attendance were clean, and well dressed.

The school is a log building with a small chancel at one end, and is used for Church purposes on Sundays. The walls are whitewashed and the V. joint ceiling is painted. A mid-day meal is served to the children in the school room. It would be much better and more conducive to tidiness in the school if a small dining room were attached to the building for this purpose.

Regina, Sask.

FROG LAKE DAY SCHOOL.

I visited this school on March the 13th and found 5 boys and 3 girls present, out of an enrollment of 13. This is quite discouraging and I spoke strongly to the parents on the matter, pointing out to them that if they were interested in keeping their school open they would have to see that the children attended regularly, or they might lose their school. This apparently had some effect for the time being, as it was noted that there were ten children at school the following morning before I left.

The school building is built with log walls and shingle roof, the chinks being plastered with mud. The building is white-washed outside and kalsomined inside. The mud shells off and it is hard to keep it looking decent. I found the school clean. There is no mid-day meal provided. The children receive two biscuits each per day. The parents put up a strong plea that a bowl of soup be provided for their children. They are very poor and I am sure that the children come to school hungry very often. The teacher informs me that the Agent has, at times, sent out a small quantity of beef and when he has been able to provide soup the attendance has shown a noticeable improvement. The teacher has a small garden and should be provided the means of fencing it. I brought several matters, of minor repairs required, to the attention of the Agent who will be able to have them carried out without incurring any expense.

Mr. A. E. Peterson, the teacher, appears to be quite capable and a man of good common sense. His presence on the reserve has a good influence and he is of
considerable assistance to the Agent in keeping him conversant with conditions.

W. Morrison,
Inspector of Agency

You will note that there is not much of a midday meal being provided here and I think we might meet the request of the parents and see that a certain amount of meat, etc., is provided so that the children could have a bowl of soup at midday, especially during the winter months, and for the year round we might send a supply of Dri-milk to this school. Dear Mr. Graham,

I visited the Frog Lake Day School on the afternoon of the 13th of October. There are 17 enrolled at this school, 10 boys and 7 girls; of these 7 boys and 6 girls were present. The attendance at this school has been better since my last visit, but there is still a great deal of room for improvement.

Since my last visit the teacher has been supplied with Drimilk during the summer months. He states that the children are not very partial to it, but they like it when boiled with rice and they have been giving it to them in this manner. This will be substituted on November 1st and during the winter months with a warm bowl of soup and tea. There is no doubt that the providing of this inexpensive meal is a great boon to the children.

The children are required to clean themselves up when they come to the school and they had adequate clothing for the season.

I reported on the condition of the school building last year. The conditions are practically the same only the school does not present so good an appearance as in the winter time as the rains had washed the mud off in streaks. Both the teacher's residence and the school are log buildings and are plastered with mud. It is hard to keep the buildings in repair and I would suggest that a small addition to the house be allowed for a summer kitchen and storage. The total cost of these repairs should not exceed $150.00.

The teacher has a small garden which was fairly good this year.

Mr. A. E. Peterson is still holding the position of teacher. He appears to be a man of good common sense and has practical experience, apart from his teaching ability, in western farming. His presence on the reserve has a good influence, but his authority over the Indians is, of course, very limited.

W. Murison, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Commissioners Office, Regina, Sask.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, giving an estimate of the cost of boring a well for the use of the Long Lake Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of your arranging for the well boring outfit mentioned by you to bore a well at this school. We note that the approximate cost, including cribbing, will be approximately $225, depending on the depth to which the well will have to be bored. You may also arrange for the purchase and installation of a pump of a suitable type, if same is required, and you should see that the well is satisfactorily completed in all respects and that there is an ample supply of water for school use.

Relative to the boring of a well by the same outfit, and at the same cost, at the Frog Lake Indian Day School, I have to say that the Department will also approve of your arranging to have a well bored at this school. It is hoped that it will not be necessary to expend any larger amount in having the work done at this school than at the Long Lake School. You may also arrange for the purchase and installation of a pump, if same is required.

The Department will leave the matter of having the wells satisfactorily completed at both the above schools in your hands to have the work carried out at the least possible expense, and after these wells have been bored, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred for each school separately.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, requesting authority to purchase the materials required for repairs at the Frog Lake and Ministikwan Indian Day Schools.

In reply I have to say that our Estimates for the current fiscal year were considerably cut and unless it is absolutely necessary that the kalsomining and painting and erection of a plank platform at the Frog Lake Day School, and the plastering of the school house and teacher's residence at the Ministikwan Day School, are urgently required, the Department would be unable to authorize having this work done this year. You might advise the Department as to the necessity for the above work at each of these schools.

You may arrange to purchase and supply screen windows and doors for the Frog Lake School. It is noted that you estimate the cost to be $21.50.

Regarding the supplying of a water filter for the Ministikwan Day School, the Department will approve of you arranging for the purchase of same at a cost not to exceed your estimate of $15.

I visited this school on the 30th of April, and found 8 pupils present out of an enrolment of 13. The average attendance for the month was 8. It appears that 6 of the pupils are fairly regular in their attendance, but the attendance of the balance is very irregular owing to their parents leaving the reserve frequently. The children who are attending regularly are making good progress.

The school is a log building, and appears to be fairly comfortable; I found both the classroom and the pupils clean. They have a teeter and a football for recreations. A mid-day meal is given to the children. I noted an improvement in the teacher's residence; the downstairs part of which has been lined with plaster board and painted. The upstairs has not been completed as there was not sufficient funds available.

Mr. A. E. Peterson, the teacher, is well qualified for his position. He also supervises the Indians on the reserve, and keeps the Agent informed regarding their activities. He is a very useful man, and a good influence on the reserve.

Sir:

I have the honour to refer to pages 7 and 9 of our 1941-1942 estimates, and to enclose herewith a requisition No. 37, for articles and material required by the four Indian Day Schools in this Agency.

All the items are urgently needed. The material, yarn, flannelette, denim and dress goods (cotton flannel) is to be made into garments for the school children by members of the Homemakers' Clubs, in conjunction with the vocational training classes of the schools.

None of the parents concerned are able to provide this extra clothing for their children, and I would earnestly request that the material be supplied if at all possible. It was allowed last year and I trust will be again as the result will be better attendance and better health.

Dear Sir:

I am attaching a Requisition in triplicate, together with a letter from Agent Cameron for materials and supplies needed for the 4 Indian Day Schools in the Onion Lake Agency.

I fully realize that the items listed are urgently needed and will at all events be a great assistance to better health and attendance in these Schools.

There might be a possible saving in purchasing these articles from a wholesale firm, which would reduce the amount requested, as noted on the Requisition.

I would recommend, if funds are at all available, that this be given the utmost consideration.

I wish to inform you while I was at the Frog Lake Day School the matter of a tank to hold water was brought to my attention and it was noted they did not have anything of that nature at the teacher's residence. The matter of eavestroughing also came up and I asked Mr. Cameron, the Agent, to look into this and let me have a report on the cost of this.

I am now in receipt of a letter from Mr. Cameron stating that we can get a good 15 barrel capacity tank made out of wood for $25.00 including the cost of labour, delivered. Long Lake Indian Day School
Frog Lake Indian Day School

I have just had a long discussion with Major Clark concerning the erection of these two schools. As the season will evidently be late by the time the supplementary estimates are brought down in the house, I would appreciate your comment on the following proposals:

1. That funds be transferred from other projects to enable the erection of the new schools required at Frog Lake and Long Lake.

2. That these schools be erected in accordance with plan 888 and that they be advertised jointly so that contractors can bid on both projects. We have found elsewhere that we were able to receive tenders much lower than when we only advertised one project.

3. That the site of the Frog Lake school should be on the property previously viewed by Mr. Clark and Mr. Taylor.

4. That the Long Lake school site be carefully investigated. The present school does not seem to serve more than half the available pupils and there is some difficulty due to the water.
Would it be possible to have a map made of the Reserve indicating the number of children of school age so that we can select a proper site for the school based on present and future needs.

I am sending a copy of this letter directly to Mr. Taylor so that you will be able to contact him directly concerning the points raised in this letter. If you can have an army message sent to me by August 12th, we can arrange to advertise for tenders.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Re: Frog Lake Day School.

This will advise that, in company with Major Clark, a recent visit was paid the Frog Lake Reserve concerning the new school site and also the matter of wells.

There is little or no trouble in finding water on this Reserve, but we run into the difficulty of sand caving in and blocking the supply. The previous wells have been dug by hand and I feel that a good well could be obtained with the use of a boring machine. Major Clark was supplied with the facts and recommended that two wells be bored (one for the school and one for the present residence) and then should one well give out without notice, the other would be available. I do not believe that these wells will have to be over 25 feet in depth and should not cost any more than the one at Goodfish Lake and the one at Long Lake, however, I intend to make enquiries on prices of cribbing, either steel or cement, in place of the usual spruce cribbing as this may eliminate our trouble in the sand.

I would therefore request that an advance of $250.00 for labour and authority to voucher for materials for cribbing. I will submit a further report in the near future regarding the prices on cribbing.

W. K. Taylor,
Superintendent.

Sir,

With further reference to the petition of the Indians of James Smith's reserve, accompanying your letter of the 5th of May, No. 33/9, I beg to say regarding the request that the Day School on that reserve be re-opened that on enquiry I found there are 18 children of school age within a radius of two miles from the school, and a few more at a greater distance. This would in my opinion quite warrant the re-opening of the school if it were not for the fact that the parents of 12 of these children are much devoted to hunting and are consequently absent with their families from the reserve for usually about 3 months beginning with October.

On examining the School Register for some years previous to the closing of the school, I found that the attendance had once been quite satisfactory, but that it had fallen off steadily for about two years before the closing.

Here as everywhere else it requires the utmost diligence on the part of the teacher.
teacher and the other officials to whose duties this matter pertains to maintain an attendance sufficiently large and regular to insure useful work; and I am of the impression that notwithstanding the hunting habits of the Indians the day school here could be kept open profitably provided the right kind of teacher could be secured. The Indians seem to recognize that if the school is re-opened a responsibility rests upon them to take the full benefit of the school by sending their children regularly. When speaking with them on the subject I emphasized this point, intimating that if it were reopened it would only be as a further trial which could not be continued long unless it proved satisfactory.

The building is still in tolerably good repair, and much of the necessary school material remains on hand.

The efforts that have hitherto been put forth to induce these Indians to send their children to the Boarding and Industrial Schools have been attended with little success, and I think it is in the interest of Indian education that another attempt be made to establish a successful Day School on this reserve.

I have the honour &c.

W.J. Chisholm

Sir,

Referring to your letter of 11th May,

No. 25334/I, and subsequent letters, I have the honour to report that I visited the Lacerte north school on the 11th instant. During the past six years I have made many visits to this school, but my last one was the only really pleasant visit made during the whole period. The attendance, thirteen, was below the average, as all Indians who can move are away hunting rats, but every boy and girl in school was interested in the work. Miss Hawley has gained their entire confidence and she has wakened them up and made them as sharp and prompt as white children. They may have been able to read before, but I never heard them, they may have been able to do sums on black board but I never saw them, they may have been able to draw, but I never saw any of their work. (I enclose a few drawings taken from Miss Hawley's desk) They I am sure, could not knit; now all the girls have learned to knit. I sent, in October, 6 pounds of yarn to the school; this has all been used up in making hoods and mitts. Miss Hawley would like very much if she could be supplied with 6 pounds more to make comforters for the girls and scarfs for the boys. From the excellent use made of what has been supplied, I trust her request will be granted.

As you are aware, at this season of the year the Indians

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Indians all go away hunting, and most of them take their families with them. This year five of Miss Hawley's girls, the eldest being fifteen, arranged that instead of going to the hunt with their parents they would all live in one house and attend school. A striking tribute to the teacher's worth.

Now to turn to Nurse Hawley: I have to report that from the 6th to the end of September she treated 17 dispensary patients, made 8 visits on calls to homes, and 5 casual visits. In October she treated 40 dispensary patients and made 15 visits. Up to the 11th November she treated 11 dispensary patients and made 18 visits. Miss Hawley is a splendid woman, has good health, is thoroughly in love with her work, and without doubt if she remains on the Reserve, the infant mortality will from now on show a decrease. The Department has been most fortunate in securing her services, and she will prove a great blessing to both old and young on the reserve.

Finding things in the above condition, I incurred some expense without authority, but as I felt that the Department would expect me to keep the work going on I acted on my own judgment. You are aware that the children of the LaCerne south school have had a mid-day meal for the past five months, and as I understood the intention was to give the north school the same treatment, I arranged for it to begin at once. We have no suitable building near the school that could be used as a kitchen, but I remembered that the Department, some years ago, sent a good sized tent to the Duck Lake Boarding school and which I knew was not in use. Miss Hawley agreed with me in thinking that it would do for the winter. I have secured the tent and shipped
shipped it to La Corne, and Farmer McCloy will see to its being put up and a floor put in. The next most important outlay was for a range, as when the Indians return I expect the average attendance at the school will be between 25 and 30, the ordinary cook stove would be too small. I also purchased the required pots, pans, etc. I further arranged, subject to your approval, with Mr. Ahenakew to drive the children to and from school at a cost of 75 cents for each trip. He will have to drive three miles in one direction and one mile in another, so that if it is to be done at all it could not be done for less. I tried to find an Indian who has a team that could do the work and also chop the wood, light the fires and sweep out the school, but none suitable could be got. I instructed Farmer McCloy to have wood hauled and chopped, the fires lit and the school swept. He thoroughly appreciates Miss Hawley's services, but his children are very young, a number of the patients are very scrupulous and while he could not very well see what could be done, he was uneasy. Nurse Hawley also spoke to me on the subject; she did not like it and it was not the right thing. Dear Sir,

As time goes on I am more thoroughly convinced that to do satisfactory work on this reserve, it is necessary to have some accommodation, at least two beds, for sick Indians. Apart from this I feel that it would be a saving to the Department in doctors' fees.

At the present time when a patient is really ill the best I can do (with my school work) is to make one visit per day unless the home happens to be near. In the majority of cases treatment is not intelligently carried out by the Indians, and they not understanding the probable consequences, advice is often not regarded seriously. The absence of every facility in their homes, and the lack of proper diet during illness, together with the too small houses, do not tend to the best results for labor expended.

Under these circumstances there are times when I do not feel justified in assuming the entire responsibility, whereas if things were so arranged that I could watch the progress, and note the response to treatment rightly administered, it would relieve the nurse of much anxiety, lessen expenses of the medical man, and result in more satisfaction to all concerned.

Fortunately, the results thus far have been in a large measure successful, and I believe the confidence of the Indians is being steadily gained, as the enclosed report will show. At first my patients consisted wholly of women and children, but the present report includes ten men.

Very truly yours,

Extract from return of the James Smith school for the quarter ending March 31, 1910.

Satisfactory progress has been made by the majority of the pupils. The attendance for January and February was good average 231/6 and 19 1/5 respectively. An epidemic of colds, coughs and "la Grippe" together with the spring hunting trips considerably lowered the average for March.

The children are members of the "Legion of the West" and contribute from time to time letters to the children's page of the Winnipeg Free Press. A year's subscription to the Weekly Edition of this paper has been donated to the school. We are hoping in the near future to have a small circulating library composed of brightly colored picture books with easy reading.

Friday afternoon of each week is devoted to knitting, crocheting, etc.

A Boys' Club has been organized with a charter membership of nine. Its object is to promote good habits among young Indian lads. Talks on various subjects followed by a social hour are given monthly by the teacher.

The catechist who is about to leave the Mission spent an afternoon at the school and gave an interesting talk to the children commending them for the good work they are doing. The children took advantage of the opportunity to present him with a handsomely bound organ edition of "The Book of Common Praise" as a slight token of their affection. A little Indian lad (No. 4, Alfred Head, aged 14) made the presentation in a manner which would have done credit to any English boy.

CHILDREN'S FAIR ON JAS. SMITH RESERVE

Any one who had chanced to pass the Mission School House at Fort-a-la-Corne (North) on Saturday last would have seen a band of more than a hundred Indians including a merry group of children dressed in their best with happy expectant faces. Was it not the day of the Fair? The First Annual Children's Fair in connection with the Mission School and a gala day it was.

In the spring the ground had been prepared and seeds sown water from the sloughs had been carried in buckets and kettles by the embryo agriculturists when rain did not favor the tiny plots. Saturday was harvest day. The exhibits were arranged on a long table and were admired by the many spectators.

To the children there never had been such good potatoes and corn such big turnips and onions grown before. The preserved berries and chocolate cakes were much in evidence as were the dormice which form part of the curriculum at this school and the results would have satisfied the taste of an epicurean. Vase after vase of flowers were there too, as the best arranged would gain a prize. A table of articles made in wool was much admired, socks mittens, hoods, mufflers, wristlets in all the colors of the rainbow.

Some of the articles were very dainty amongst them being a child's hood and booties crocheted in pale blue Berlin decorated with satin ribbon. A rich dark red muffler with black border and a pale pink scarf.

Rev. Edward Ahnakeew, Chief James Head and Pat Britton kindly acted as judges.

The presence for a short time of Mr. MacArthur, Indian Agent was much appreciated and his evident interest in the Indian children's efforts should be a stimulus to greater things in the future.

The Union Jack floated over the Central tent in which Indian girls presided at a well arranged tea table prettily decorated with parsley and served tea to all visitors.

Miss Turner kindly favored us with several selections on the "phonograph" which were greatly appreciated. An interesting programme of sports followed after which "Fair Canada" was rendered by the children.

Three hearty cheers were given for the Department of Indian Affairs and for all those who had contributed towards making it possible to hold the First Annual Children's Fair on Jas. Smith's Reserve.

After singing the National Anthem the Redmen returned to their homes, with visions of another Fair day in their mind's eye.

The temporary hospital which was in operation five months did satisfactory work and was a real blessing. It is to be hoped the Department may see its way to continue this very necessary branch of work. Its absence has been keenly felt on several occasions during the past few months. It is almost useless to try to do anything for a really ill patient in a living room with from six to eight people all sleeping upon the floor and no ventilation. I believe a nurse's full time could be spent by careful supervision of the homes and people on the reserve. The presence of a graduate nurse on the northern portion of James Smith's reserve with 200 Indians, has necessitated calling in a doctor but once in case of illness and once for a fractured femur during the past 10½ months.

We have just re-produced a letter from a resident of the James Smith Indian Reserve. It was refused publication by the Kinistino Rep., but as the parties in question hold public offices, we take Mr. Godfrey's word for it that it is in the public interest. It is illegal to assume the title of "Doctor" in this province without holding a licence, even where the party using the title has that right elsewhere.

To the Editor of the Rep:
"The man who works the hardest may not draw the biggest pay.
The one with deepest knowledge may not have the most to say.
But the man who is most modest gets the last seat in the rear.
And the one who blows his bugle is the one whom people hear."

Sir:

The above quotation, which appeared in your issue of Nov. 23, gives me an opening to write upon a subject, which has been in my mind for some time, viz.—the fallaciousness of title of "The Medicine Woman" assumed by your continual correspondent from Fort a la Corne.

The Bluebook of 1911, which has just been issued gives TWO names who are classed as Teacher and Matron in James Smiths' Reserve, and while no report is made of the success, or otherwise of the nursing part of the duties of "the Medicine Woman" at the north school, special mention is made of the successful nursing work done by the Teacher and Matron at the south school.

"By their fruits ye shall know them."

It is always considered good breeding to leave others the awarding of praise for work done. In this case however, your correspondent claims a title to which she has not the prior right, and which she should have left to others to confer.

Some four years ago the teacher at the south school was appointed as Dispenser of Medicine. Before that time, and long before the arrival of "The Medicine Woman" this teacher answered the call to sicknesses to all parts of the Reserve, both Fort a la Corne and Big Head's Indians, without remuneration or any tooting of the horn. She left this for officials to do, and the result was the appointing of a female teacher at the north school who also had qualifications as a nurse.

This was a tribute to the work done by the teacher at the south school.

I have never heard any Indian call either of the matrons "The Medicine Woman" either in Cree or English.

Anyone not in the know would naturally think it was a title conferred by the Indians, but no sir, it has only been assumed by "The Medicine Woman" who is continually "blowing her own bugle."

I am,

"The man who gets the last seat in the rear"

Yours Sincerely

Dec. 8. Wm. Godfrey, Fort a la Corne

My dear Mr. Scott:

I was glad to get your letter. It is always an inspiration and encouragement to know that the work on the outskirts as it were, is being closely followed by those at the "hub" - of Affairs.

I hope to write you later at some length, this is only a note to tell you that under present conditions, I am very unhappy in this Agency.

I could write at some length upon this subject, but perhaps it would be unbecoming for me in a subordinate position to criticise an official. At the same time I do feel that the Department demands justice shown to its employees.

I have now given nearly four years of continuous service to the Department. I have given the best that in me lies, to the work, and have remained in it, though during this time, five calls have come in to go elsewhere. This is sufficient to justify my statement that I'm really interested in Indian Work. The story of my four years here, is one of advancement.

To give you an idea of the attitude of Mr. Agent Schmidt I am enclosing a letter with a copy of my reply.

I wish to make the following comments.

I. Mr. McCloy, did not send any letter to the Agent that I had been purchasing supplies for the Constants.

II. No account has been "cut out" At the Hudson's Bay Co's Store, and the officer at the Post does not know what the Agent means.

I would have forwarded this letter sooner but I wished to give the Agent the opportunity of either an explanation or an apology.

The matter was brought before him on the occasion of his last visit - he was unable to give an explanation and seemingly flew angry.

The only purchase that I have made during the past year at the Hudson's Bay Co's Store was some mustard and some thin cloth with which to use; this was made for a critically ill boy, McDonald Moostosokamasis, and I consider it came under the head of my duties.

Our supplies had not come and it was a case of emergency. I am no irresponsible child, and I feel that the Department expects its employees to have intelligence enough to act wisely in emergencies. However, Mr. Schmidt's letter could not possibly refer to this purchase.

His letter to me wounded me more deeply from the fact, that Mr. McCloy has treated me in a most discourteous manner, ever since my arrival here. This, I might say was owing to an oversight of the then Agent - but this is a long story -

Has the Department any position to offer me, in some other than the Duck Lake Agency?-

Believe me,

Faithfully Yours,

The Medicine Woman, as she is called, has been engaged in the work of promoting the physical, mental and moral betterment of the brown folk at the Reserve, for Miss Hawley has not confined her activities to nursing; though as a trained nurse, she is specially versed in the care of the sick. Dear Sir:

Would it be possible for myself and wife to obtain a transfer to another position in the Indian School work, and if so what steps would be necessary to secure same?

My wife has been Field Matron and teacher at Fort ala Corne Day School since November 11-1913. Our relations with Indian agent and the Department have been very satisfactory on our part.

Our reasons for wishing a transfer are:- Owing to migration of many families from this part of Reserve to south end of same to open up new farms and the fact that those remaining are mainly hunting Indians who take their children away with them, the attendance has decreased until we feel that our usefulness here is about over. It is possible that a new teacher and matron could build up the work here for a time where we are unable to influence them longer.

Mrs Shaw is finding her work here to be too heavy especially during the winter months. Her health will not permit her to continue.
making the cold winter drives that she is compelled to do in the work here. Between five and six hundred visits a year in camp besides her duties in school is too heavy work for her. We feel that a position in a milder climate would be better for her.

If it is possible to give us work in some other locality it would be much appreciated. Would prefer some place on coast in British Columbia but would accept any position you have where we have work together.

We should be sorry inclined to quit the Indian School service and trust that some place will be open for us. I have informed our Agent Curt Schmidt of our wishing a transfer and trust that he will furnish any data that you may not have regarding us and our work.

I am yours sincerely,

Henry W Shaw,

Mr. Scott,

With reference to that portion of Mr. Inspector Crombie's report on the day schools on the James Smiths Reserve which deals with the North School I beg to say that, in view of the fact that the Indians are moving from the neighbourhood of the school to the southern portion of the reserve and the consequent falling off of the attendance, I think that Mr. Crombie's suggestion that the school be closed should be acted on.

A letter has just come in from Mr. Shaw, the teacher of this school, asking for a transfer for himself and his wife, who is acting as field matron on the reserve, to some other locality, as he considers their usefulness is gone as far as the work at this end of the reserve is concerned, owing to the migration of the Indians mentioned in Mr. Crombie's report.

Mr. Crombie suggested that Mr. Shaw and his wife be transferred to Sturgeon Lake, if the James Smiths North School is closed. It is a pity that this suggestion was not made sooner, as Miss Martha Coburn was appointed to the Sturgeon
Sturgeon Lake School on the 26th ultimo on the recommendation of Bishop Newnham. She is young and inexperienced and Mr. Shaw would be much better for the position.

Miss Swift, the present field matron on the Sturgeon Lake Reserve, might be appointed to the position of nurse at The Pas Boarding School. Archdeacon MacKay has been authorized to obtain a nurse for the school and, if arrangements could be made to send the Shaws to Sturgeon Lake, Miss Swift could be transferred to The Pas.

Acting on Mr. Inspector Crombie's report, Bishop Newnham was written to on the 30th ultimo and informed of the Department's decision to close the North School on the James Smiths Reserve and it was suggested that Mr. and Mrs. Shaw might be transferred to Sturgeon Lake. His Lordship was also informed that, if this transfer were carried out, Miss Swift could be sent to the MacKay Boarding School and he was asked to advise the Department as soon as possible whether this arrangement would meet with his approval.

I have delayed answering Mr. Shaw's letter until a reply is received from Bishop Newnham.

In the event of the closing of the North school I do not see that anything could be done with the buildings at present. According to Mr. Crombie it would be next to impossible
impossible to move them to another locality on the reserve and, as we have no funds available for rebuilding on the South end of the Reserve, it would be better to defer going to any expense on the buildings there until the Indians are permanently settled, as it may be possible to secure a site which would be more convenient for all the Indians on the reserve.

Should the Shaws leave, the question of the appointment of a matron to succeed Mrs. Shaw at the North end could stand over for the present.

With reference to File No. 16505/7 re day schools on James Smith's Reserve, Fort la Corne, Sask.

I have today written a letter in reply to Department letter of 18th September in reference to schools on this reserve. After perusal of the file I have no doubt that you will agree with me that the north school should be closed at once.

I understand Bishop Newnham is finding it difficult to secure Teachers for Day Schools where vacancies occur. Sturgeon Lake Day School is a case in point. The trouble at Sturgeon Lake is that on this Reserve Miss Swift, a maiden lady, acts as Matron and the Bishop apparently wants to get a married man as Teacher whose wife would act as Matron. Mr. Shaw, James Smith's Reserve, is well spoken of by Mr. Agent Schmidt as a teacher although I have not had an opportunity of judging in the matter, as my visits to the reserve were made at a time when the schools were not in session. Would it not be well in this case to have Mr. and Mrs. Shaw transferred to Sturgeon Lake Reserve as Teacher and Matron and Miss Swift transferred from Sturgeon Lake to James Smith's Reserve as Matron. Miss Swift, who is handicapped in her work through deafness, has had considerable experience in nursing and understands the use of drugs and for this reason her services are of value.
It has been suggested by Mr. Grain, in his letter to the Department dated Octr 15th., that Miss Swift be transferred to Carlton headquarters to act as Matron there.

Dear Sir:

I beg to report that in accordance with instructions contained in your letter dated the 7th inst. No.305-14 with which you enclosed a copy of a letter to you from Mr. Scott regarding the question of re-opening the South Fort la Corne Day school. I went fully into the matter when at that point on the 23rd instant.

The removal of the buildings from the North to the South end of the Reserve would not appear to be practicable owing to the nature of the country between the two points, which is comprised of slightly rolling ridges between which are sloughs or pot holes. The ridges especially towards the north end of the reserve are covered with a fairly heavy growth of poplar through which a road would have to be cut for the passage of the buildings.

Experienced men would have to be engaged to carry out the work and this would entail considerable expense. It does not appear to me that the situation would be met on this reserve by re-opening only one of the schools. The following are my reasons for arriving at this opinion.

The north school is located near the north east line and the south school near the south west line of the reserve. The distance between the schools being approximately nine miles. The homes of the Indians are scattered over the whole of the area between and on each side. I find that there are 14 children of school age within a three mile radius of the north school and 16 children within the same radius of the south school. There are six children of school age residing at a greater distance than three miles from either of these schools.

The largest centres of the population on this reserve are at the north and south ends and the schools are at present located as fairly as possible in order to provide for the best possible attendance at each. Judging from past experience there is no guarantee that either of these schools will have a satisfactory attendance until it is made compulsory and the Act is enforced.

The dwelling house at the south school is a log building 16'x 18' with a small kitchen attached. It is old and the foundation logs are rotten. It has one room upstairs and one on the ground floor. Lighting is provided by one window on each side. It would have to be replaced before the school is re-opened.

The school room is built with logs the walls have been willowed and plastered. The plaster has been knocked off for about two feet from the bottom and the logs are rotted. Repairs are out of the question as there is no solid material to nail to. It is heated with a box stove and the floors must be cold in winter. Water is obtained at a depth of 40 feet but I am told that it is very alkaline. This is a condition which prevails over the whole south end of the reserve and the adjacent country. Soft water storage facilities would appear advisable as a help in this connection.

W.M.Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina.
The old well is out of business and a new one will have to be dug.

I may say in conclusion that the Rev'd Canon McLellan called upon me and we had a talk on the school question. He stated that in his opinion a good average attendance could be obtained at both schools and that he did not favour the re-opening of one of the schools more than the other. It appears to be his desire to have educational facilities provided for the children of this band.

He suggested that instead of putting up new buildings at the south end of the reserve that the money be used in enlarging the north school so as to provide residential accommodation for the children. This of course would mean a boarding school which no doubt would meet the situation if the Department favored the plan.

I trust that the foregoing report contains the information which you require.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Very Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the last instant regarding the re-opening of a school on the James Smith's Reserve.

In reply I beg to say that a report has been received regarding the condition of the school buildings at both the north and south ends of the reserve and also as to the probable attendance. The buildings at the south end are unfit to be used for school purposes, while those at the north end are in good condition. Mr. Inspector Murison states that there are fourteen children of school age within the three mile radius of the north school.

The Department has decided, on the recommendation of the Inspector and Mr. Commissioner Graham, to authorize the re-opening of the school on the north end of the reserve, known as the James Smith's Indian Day School. I shall therefore, be pleased if the church authorities will nominate a suitable teacher for this school to begin duties as soon as possible. A single teacher, male or female, having the necessary qualifications will be required. As the attendance will likely be small, the Department can only pay a salary at the rate of $750.00 per annum, together with the bonus at the rate of $150.00 per annum during the period which it is continued to teachers in Indian day schools. I have the honour to forward herewith for your perusal copies of communications received from Mr. R.B.F. Taylor, teacher at the Fort à la Corne North Day School on the James Smith Reserve.

Mr. Taylor is a widower with no family. Having lost a leg, which he claims cannot be replaced by an artificial limb, he has to use crutches. He is very nervous and not physically strong. I consider, and have brought the fact to his attention, that it is most unwise for him to live alone as he is doing at present, having left the Farm Instructor's house where he was boarding to live in the teacher's house. He cannot remain alone during the winter months, and I am not prepared to recommend employing someone to live with him; I have told him so but he does not seem to give the matter serious thought. From personal observation I find this man to be very unsettled as to his future actions, and he changes his mind frequently.

Immediately on assuming his duties as teacher on this reserve last winter Mr. Taylor adopted an aggressive attitude, and displayed an inclination to meddle with matters entirely outside his province. Later he unfortunately closed off somewhat with the parents of some of his pupils, and when I investigated the matter he made some talk of resigning his position. While he may have the ability to teach satisfactorily, I find him very slack in handling his own end of the work, that is in making his reports and returns. In checking up his Quarterly Return for March 1921, a period that included 18 school days in the month of March, I found that the school had been open for 13 days only in that month. The month of April disclosed the fact that the school had been closed 3 days when it should have been open. On taking the matter up with Mr. Taylor, the explanations furnished were not very satisfactory, and it also involves the trouble of making readjustments in a subsequent return.

The question of an exchange of transfers between himself and Mr. Lowe of the John Smiths Day School is entirely out of the question. Mr. Lowe is settled in his position and is doing good work at his school, and, as far as I am aware, has no desire for an exchange.

Taking all circumstances into consideration I beg to suggest that the Department accept Mr. Taylor's resignation, nevertheless I would prefer that the Department take what action in the matter they see fit.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary.

My Lord,

Hearing that the position of School Teacher at the Indian School at Fort a la Corne, James Smith's Reserve, is to become vacant at the end of August next, I beg to offer my services to fill the vacancy beginning on September 1st.

As you are aware, I have had considerable experience in Indian teaching, having taught school on the above Reserve (at the South Fort a la Corne school) from 1903-1912, the success of which may be verified by the records of the Indian Blue Books of those years.

I may perhaps add that, although I opened that new school with children who had never been in a school before, yet, when I left, that school was the proud possessor of two diplomas, and one silver medal (each suitably framed by the Dept of Indian Affairs) which my scholars had won in competition at the Winnipeg Industrial Exhibition.

Indeed, without any undue egotism on my part, I think I may venture to say, that it was partly due to the success of my teaching, and to the suggestions which I put to the Indian Dept., through correspondence, at its request, as to the means to be employed for the further improvement of Indian schools, that the "New Improved Way Schools" became an accomplished fact.

This said correspondence will be on file in the records of the Indian Dept., and all I have above stated may be corroborated by Duncan C. Scott Esq., Deputy Superintendent of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, who visited my school in 1910.

In 1912, my work at South Fort a la Corne terminated but was continued at Sturgeon Lake Indian Reserve, in conjunction with my husband; the latter as school
teaching, and myself as matron. This position was held till June 1914, when, at my doctor's order, I was obliged to relinquish the work on account of the break-down of my health.

Perfect restoration has followed my long rest, during the whole of which period I have ever had the longing to return to the Indian work, and have continuously kept in touch with my old scholars by correspondence.

I hold an English 2nd Class Teacher's Certificate having been fully trained in the Old Country, my marks falling only a very few short of entitling me to a First Class; indeed, of the number of teachers who wrote with me, I stood the highest in that class, at that Branch.

The following Certificates are also held by me:

1. First Class (Elementary) Singing
2. First Class (Advanced) Singing
3. Elementary Freehand Drawing
4. Advanced Freehand Drawing
5. Perspective Drawing
6. Physiology
7. Nursing Diploma from the "Chautauqua School of Nursing," New York.

Hoping that these facts may be deemed sufficient to entitle me to resume my work among the Indians, and that my application may be favourably received,

Note. I cordially recommend Mrs Ada A. Godfrey. Her appointment will be perfectly satisfactory to me. Her character & her abilities have been proved in past experience.

I beg to remain Yours obediently

(Mrs Wm.) Ada A. Godfrey

Dear sir-

I was called to Fort ala Corne reserve yesterday to visit some sick Indians and while there was asked to see Mr Taylor, the schoolteacher.

Mr Taylor should be in a hospital, at least for a time, so as to be under observation. He is getting extremely thin and debilitated and needs official care. I am strongly suspicious that his condition may be due to drug addiction and should be where he can be watched.

You are no doubt aware that serious charges of dishonesty are laid against him. He appears to be using his position to obtain credit and loans, which to all appearances will not be met. The last time he was in Melfort he came to me and borrowed $10.00 on the story that he came here intending to return the same day, but the Indian who was with him would not go back until the next day, so he was put to the unexpected expense of stopping at the hotel overnight.

At that time I was under the impression that his story that he was a returned soldier and wounded while in the Army was O.K., but it seems information has been sought in Australia from Army Office and at present no trace can be found that he is on the pension list, which he certainly would be if he lost his leg in service. His conduct certainly needs looking into as well as his health.

Yours sincerely,

Sgd. M.D. Baker.
Sir,

I have the honour to inform you that on the 12th inst., a telephone message was received at this office from The Secretary Municipality of Kinistino, Sask., stating that Mr. R.E.F. Taylor, teacher at the Fort a la Corne, North Day School on James Smith's Reserve had been brought to Kinistino and it was feared was out of his mind, and asking what should be done with him and who should pay the expenses.

Mr. Ewing, Clerk at the Agency here, who answered the phone in my absence, stated that he replied to take him to a hospital and that the matter of payment would be taken up later.

Yesterday I received from Dr. M.D. Baker of Melfort "Medical Attendant to James Smith's Band" a letter, a copy of which is attached hereto. This letter which is not dated, must have been written and mailed not later than the evening of the 11th, in order to reach here on the 13th. After receiving this letter I phoned Dr. Baker who told me that Mr. Taylor had been brought to The Melfort Hospital and was there under his care, that he was very weak, temperature below normal, recognized him, the Doctor, and knew what was going on, but that he would have to be kept in the Hospital under observation for a certain time.

I asked Dr. Baker if he had any objections to my forwarding a copy of his letter to the Dept., to which he replied "you may do as you please about it". As regards charges of dishonesty etc., referred to in the Doctor's letter, while I have heard rumors of same, these have not been brought to my attention "Officially" and I have not given same any special attention. I understand that Mr. Taylor is hard up financially, that he has no money, and the matter of paying the Dr. and Hospital is one which will no doubt be brought to The Department's attention in the very near future.

I am today forwarding, enclosed herewith, his Quarterly School Return for the quarter ending Dec. 31st last, on which you will notice, written in red ink in the remarks column, that he requests that his salary and bonus cheques be sent direct, care Merchants Bank of Canada, Kinistino, Sask. From reports, I hear that he has promissory notes to meet at the Bank. If this is the case and his Salary and Bonus cheques are applied thereon, there will be nothing left to pay the Dr. and Hospital.
I suggest that Mr. Taylor's Military service record be looked into with a view of ascertaining whether he did serve during the late war with the Australian Army, which he claims he did.

I am leaving for Melfort by Monday's train to see Mr. Taylor.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Sir:

I have the honour to request that you give the following the attention which you may consider it due same.

I was engaged as Teacher and Dispenser of the James Smith Reserve on 22nd July 1920. For a while - being a widower - I stayed with the Farm Instructor; but we had not much in harmony and therefore I moved my belongings over to the Teacher's residence.

Being incapacitated by the loss of a limb, I lost an Indian boy in to stay with me and everything went well until the early part of this year when I was taken sick and had to be removed to the hospital where I was for seven weeks. Just previous to leaving that institution, the Indian Agent - C. P. Schmidt - called on me and told me that I would not be required further on the James Smith Reserve, and I am writing to ask you whether I am not entitled to a month's notice or a month's salary. Now I am stranded, I have no work in sight and my sickness has thrown very heavy on my purse. I would, therefore, appreciate it if you would consider this letter for all its weight, and if possible send me a cheque direct. It would further be appreciated if you would let me know the reason for my discharge.

I have the honour to be,

to take me all my time to settle. All this time - my foot previously described - was
getting worse, consequently I was compelled to seek medical advice with the result that I
was told that amputation of the toes were necessary, therefore, on the 27th March, I came to
the above Hospital and was operated upon on March 29 and am to be operated again on April
10th for the same purpose. It makes it doubly hard for me for I am already incapacitated
by the loss of one leg and now with the toes off the other foot I shall find it very difficult to
get along. Since I was in your employment at the time of the two accidents, I was wondering
whether you could do anything for me towards helping me to meet part of the expense or to
help me to live after I am discharged from work or before I obtain any lucrative employment.

I have the honour to be,

Gentlemen,
your obedient servant,
P.B. Fielden Taylor.

P.S. Since I am thoroughly conversant in languages & stenographical work perhaps you
could help me to a position as clerk at one of your Indian Agencies.
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Gentlemen:

I have the honour to request that you give the following proper personal and consideration.

During the summer of 1921 whilst I was in your employment in the capacity of Teacher and Dispenser on the James Smith Reserve, Fort a la Corne, Sask., I had the misfortune of burning my foot badly with Carbolic Acid whilst treating a case on said Reserve.

During the winter of 1921-22, I further had the misfortune to freeze my foot whilst driving out to a sick case on said Reserve; and although the said foot was in a bad shape yet I did not lose one day in the Reserve from it, but still carried on.

On January 9th, 1922, I was removed from the James Smith Reserve to the Melfort Hospital where I was an inmate for seven weeks and four days suffering...
OTTAWA, April 19th, 1922.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, in which you request that the Department come to your assistance by way of paying part of the expenses incurred by you for hospital treatment, or that you be given employment as clerk at one of the Indian agencies.

In reply I beg to say we regret that it will not be possible to furnish any assistance towards your expenses, as we have no funds from which such a payment could be made.

There are no vacancies at any of the agencies in which the services of a clerk are required.

Your obedient servant,

[Russell T. Ferrier]
Supt. of Indian Education.

Very Reverend Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 12th instant, informing the Department that Mr. J. L. Lowe, Teacher of the school on the John Smith's Reserve, requests to be transferred to the school on the James Smith's Reserve, and stating the reasons for desiring this exchange.

In reply I beg to say that there would be a difficulty in making this exchange. Mrs. Lowe is Field Matron, and her position has been established by the Civil Service Commission. If this transfer were made and her services retained, it would be necessary to have the position of Field Matron for the James Smith's Reserve established by the Civil Service Commission. The Department has not considered the appointment of a field matron for this last named reserve.

The salary allowed Mr. Goodman is at the rate of $750 per annum plus bonus; the salary paid Mr. Lowe is $600 per annum plus bonus and Mrs. Lowe, as Field Matron, $480 plus bonus.

In view of the above, the Department does not consider it advisable at the present time to arrange an exchange in positions between Mr. Goodman and Mr. Lowe, without some stronger reason being given therefor than has been up to this time set forth.

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 23rd ultimo No.109-4-1 re the attendance being quite irregular, and the pupils not punctual at the Fort a la Corne North Day School on James Smith's reserve and asking me to make a recommendation as to methods that can be adopted to remedy this condition.

In reply, I beg to say that there are several reasons why this condition exists. In many cases the parents are illiterate, are indifferent regarding educational matters, and do not see to it that their children attend school regularly, and leave home early enough that they may arrive at school on time. Also, in many cases the child rules the home, and any excuse advanced by the child for not going to school is accepted by the parents. Others take their families along when they leave the reserve to go hunting, trapping, digging Sandroot, or pick berries. We have succeeded in some cases to have them leave their children with relatives or neighbors, but when the child begins to cry, or runs after their parents at the time of their leaving they nine times out of ten give in to the child and take him along.

I have, on every occasion possible, spoken to the parents individually, and to the band in meeting, on the necessity of sending their children to school regularly. Rev. R. McNamara, missionary on the reserve, is doing likewise. The Indians, while seeming to approve of what we tell them, will give the matter attention for a few days, but soon forget and the same condition again prevails.

The warning that the children will have to be sent to Boarding schools if they do not attend the Day schools regularly, is no longer effective as they would be willing to send them away.

The appointment of a Truah officer might help matters, but this would necessitate an outsider, as I doubt if any member of the band would have the required authority to enforce the law. If a member of The Royal Canadian Mounted Police could be got to patrol the reserve about once a month, I believe it would help the attendance considerably.

I have the honour to be

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
