Indian Act. (School attendance)

Acting on instructions received from the Office Commanding of "F" Division on December 5th last, I left Prince Albert on the afternoon of the same date with orders to report to Mr. Goodman at Fort-à-la-Come.

On the morning of the 7th last, I visited the school on the reserve during the school hours and noticed that the attendance was better than what it was on my previous patrol to the reserve. Mr. Goodman informed me that the children were attending better at the present time than they had been doing before my previous patrol, also that they were coming to school on time now, whereas before some of them were always about two hours late in getting to school.

On my previous patrol to the reserve, Mr. Goodman informed me that one of the boys Simon Brittain son of Andrew Brittain was not attending school and had not been doing so for some time as his grandparents Samuel Smith had the boy away hunting with him, and had just returned to the reserve so I called on the grandparents and told them that the boy would have to attend school. In my visit to the reserve on the 7th last, Mr. Goodman informed me that this boy had not attended school since the last patrol, as the grandparents had taken him away hunting with them again shortly after I had left the reserve the last time. I visited some of the reserve Indians on the reserve on this patrol and made inquiries concerning the whereabouts of this boy and his grandparents and was informed that they were still away hunting. Mr. Jo-don the farm instructor on the reserve informed me that this boy's father was away hunting since last spring up in the Isle-à-Cross district, and that before he left the reserve he left the boy with Pota-Husetase so that the boy could attend school, but shortly after the father left the grandparents claimed the boy stating that before the mother died she had given her charge of the boy. She also informed that lately she stated that she would take the boy away hunting with them where ever she liked. It appears that the only way to get this boy to attend school would be to put him in one of the boarding schools.

There is a lot of children of school age living at the south end of the reserve that can't attend school on account of being too away from the school at the north end of the reserve, and the school at the south end has been closed for some time.

Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a report, forwarded by the Commissioner of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, from the constable who patrolled the James Smith's Indian Reserve early in December, last, regarding the enforcing of school attendance.

The constable in his report has drawn attention to the case of a boy named Simon Brittain, son of Andrew Brittain, who has not attended school for some time as his grandfather, Samuel Smith, had the boy away hunting with him. The constable also states it would appear that the only way to get this boy to attend school would be to put him in one of the boarding schools. I have to request that you will arrange as soon as possible to have this boy placed in a residential school of the faith to which he belongs. You should have an application prepared on the form for that purpose and signed by the father or the person responsible for his care. If the father or other interested party refuses to sign the application, you may take the necessary steps, under the Indian Act, to have the boy placed in a residential school.

I shall be pleased to be advised at a later date as to the action taken in his case.

Acting under instructions from the C.O. "Y" Div., I beg to report I patrolled through the Fort a La Corne Indian Reserve on 28th May last & on the 29th ult., I visited the school.

I interviewed the school-teacher, Mr. Goodman & he informed me that there was only a small attendance at the present time on account of seven children having been taken from the school & transferred to the boarding school. There was also two absences cases & upon investigating these, I found that one of them was a case of toothache & in the other case I found that the father of the child, Jacob Twiet, was contemplating making a trip down the river picking roots & was taking the child with him, but after a little persuasion, I managed to get him to make arrangements with a neighbour to look after his child until he returned, & the girl again attend school that afternoon.

Mr. Goodman strongly advised that a patrol be made before the latter part of August, before the school opened after the holidays, as there would be several children of school age by that time & the parents would not likely send them to school unless they saw that the police patrol was on the job.

In conclusion, I beg to state I found that I otherwise found everything on the reserve in good shape, no cases of drunkenness, etc. to investigate.

The Commissioner,
R.C.M.Police,
Ottawa, Ont.

Forwarded for his information.
Another patrol will be made to this Reserve about the time suggested by the teacher.
Copy sent to Indian Agent Schmidt of Duck Lake.

F.J.A. Demers
Supt.
Commanding "Y" Division.

Prince Albert.

Ottawa, January 30, 1925.

Sir:

I wish to refer to that portion of your No. 309-9 of the 22nd instant, which relates to the education of the children on the James Smith Reserve. You will remember that it is your intention to discuss with Mr. Inspector Morrison the advisability of moving the Fort a la Corne North day school ten miles to the south of the reserve, where there are a large number of our wards of school age.

From reports on file, it appears that there are 26 children of school age living within two miles of the site of the old Fort a la Corne South school. In addition to these, there are 3 children six years of age and 24 still younger in the same area. These facts have been taken from a comprehensive report of Mr. Indian Agent Schmidt dated May 22, 1923. The local Church of England missionary and His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan have on several occasions urged the re-opening of the Fort a la Corne South Indian day school. R.C.M.P. officers who have patrolled the reserve have also drawn our attention to the number of children at the south end.

There are no suitable buildings available, with the exception of the stable; so the provision of a classroom and a teacher's residence would have to be made. In addition, a well is required.

Some time ago the question of moving the Fort a la Corne North school buildings to the south of the reserve was discussed. After serious consideration, it was decided not to proceed with this undertaking. Today the problem is unchanged, as there has been in the North school an enrolment of 15 during the present academic year. The average attendance was never higher than 12 for any one quarter, but the teacher, Mr. Goodman, who is apparently doing good work, reports that eight additional children will be ready for school this coming summer. However, if the reserve is to be reduced in the immediate future by selling a portion of it, this scheme of moving the buildings might be considered, if the north part of the reserve is to be relinquished.

Please keep these facts in mind during your deliberations, and when you are discussing the question with Mr. Murison, make a recommendation to the Department. At the present writing, there is in the draft of the Estimates for Indian Education 1925-26 an item of $4,000 to build a combined school and teacher's residence at Fort a la Corne South.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Aast. Deputy and Secretary.

F. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

The Right Reverend the Lord Bishop of Saskatchewan.

Bishopsthorpe, Prince Albert,
Saskatchewan.

My Lord,

The Indians of this band, whose children have been taken to the Elkhorn Boarding School, wish to have them returned; the reasons being as follows:

1. All the children from the James Smith Band, who were in the MacKay Boarding School, were removed to the Elkhorn Boarding School with neither the consent nor knowledge of the parents.

2. The Elkhorn School is too far from Fort a la Corne for visiting children in case of sickness or for holiday travel. The expense being too great.

3. The children have been in ill health since going there & there has been one death & several others are on the sick list.

4. In the event of it being necessary for children from this band to attend a Boarding School, we would wish them to attend a school within the Diocese of Saskatchewan.

5. The Elkhorn Boarding School was misrepresented to the Indians of this band by Mr Ely, the Principal, who gave us to understand that it was an Industrial School.

On behalf of The James Smith Band,

Signed, [Signature]
Chief James Head

Dear Sir,

In further reference to my letter to you with regard to the depletion of the Day School on Fort la Corne Reserve:

I send you enclosed two statements, the one being the Petition from the Chief and band on the occasion of my visit to the reserve recently for Confirmation, and also the statement of the Teacher of the Day school who put this statement in writing at my request.

The children of this band have been taken out of the Diocese systematically, those who were at the McKay Boarding school were taken to Elkhorn, as the chief says without their knowledge, and some of them only knew about the removal after the death of one child.

The others were taken from the Day school with the consent of the chief on the statement that they would be much better off at Elkhorn as it was to be an "Industrial" school. Now they know it was not.

I may say that I am very much annoyed at this "Brigand" way of dealing with these children. This man Ely, from another diocese and another province, comes into one of our Missions and is told by a Roman Catholic Agent that he is free to do as he likes and take and leave what he pleases. Without any reference to Bishop, Missionary, or teacher these children are taken by misrepresentation to the Indians to a distant school.

The Agent silences the teacher by the statement that the Church hires him but he the agent fires him and at 24 hours notice too.

The teacher thinks his school has been purposely depleted in order to give colour of excuse for "firing" him. Those he has left are so diseased that during the cold weather they cannot attend school.
This man Elys statement that he acted with the authority of "The House of Bishops" and of Commissioner Graham, I can of course deal with in another way. He is a clergyman and is subject to the canonical jurisdiction of his Bishop but that is quite aside from this "pirate" way of destroying the Day schools in order to fill the Residence schools.

The school at Mistawasis has been depleted in the same way and it is quite evident to us on the ground that it is part of a systematic attack to extinguish the Day schools in favour of the Residence schools.

This matter has already come before the Executive Committee of the Diocese and without a single voice in opposition a strong resolution was passed against the action of the M.S.C.C. Committee in Winnipeg in allowing or encouraging these things on the part of their agents.

That of course must be taken up through Church channels, but the killing of the Day Schools is a serious question for the Department as well, and as such this case is reported to you as a test case representing what we in this diocese consider a vicious tendency behind it viz the draining and then the suppression of the Day Schools on the reserves.

Believe me to be

Yours very faithfully,

The Right Reverend the Lord Bishop of Saskatchewan.

Bishopstherpe, Prince Albert,
Saskatchewan.

My Lord,

On the 14th day of March 1924 this school was visited by the Rev. Mr. Ely of Elk Horn & the Indian Agent C. P. Schmidt of Duck Lake. They inspected the school & Mr. Ely selected 7 (seven) of my most promising pupils & informed me that he was taking them away to the Reopened Industrial School at Elk Horn. I was not consulted neither was I given the slightest consideration. He informed me that he had his authority from The House of Bishops, which is the reason for my not having written you at the time, & from Commissioner Graham, Regina. Agent C. P. Schmidt informed him in front of me; that he had a free hand to do as he pleased. He had some of the children undress, so that he could examine their condition, & those that were too repulsively diseased he told me I could keep. At this date I had 15 children on the school roll, & the school was being regularly attended. The average attendance for the quarter being 12.25 as my reports will show.

Now, at the time of Mr. Ely's visit, there were at the South End of this Reserve, which is another school district, the school being closed as the buildings have been condemned by the Indian Department, & which is eight or more miles from this school, not less than 40 Indian children of school age, who had absolutely no opportunity of going to school. For reasons best known to himself, he did not take them; they are still running wild & neglected; while my school was robbed of half its pupils.

Previous to Mr. Ely's visit, Agent C. P. Schmidt removed from my school 4 of my pupils & took them to the Gordon Boarding School.

Since I came here I have done my best to make this school a success & at one time I had 19 pupils attending; but it has never been given a fair trial or chance, as it has been systematically emptied.

The above is a true & faithful statement & I am prepared to take oath on it.

I remain, My Lord,

Your obedient servant,

Ernest B. Goodman

Ottawa, March 12, 1925.

Dear Bishop Lloyd:

I have Your Lordship's letter of the 4th instant, relative to recruiting the pupils of the Fort a la Corne North Indian Day School for residential schools. At the outset, I wish to assure you that the Department's aim is to maintain whatever schools, both day and residential, are found to be necessary for the training of the youth of our wards. Your Lordship may assure Mr. Goodman, the teacher, that there is no intention of depleting his school and then dispensing with his services. You may also inform the Indians of the James Smith band that the Elkhorn Indian Residential School is an industrial school and that the children are given an education along both vocational and academic lines. The Department has discontinued the use of the words "Boarding" and "Industrial", but if the old classification still obtained, the Elkhorn school would rank as an industrial one.

With reference to the general question raised by Your Lordship, I wish to refer you to official letters 160-2 of November 8th and January 9th, last.

Yours very truly,

J. D. McLean

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

My Lord and Dear Sir;

Mrs. Bird is an English trained certificate teacher, she was granted a Second class certificate on her qualifications, and will be granted a First class whenever she gets another Inspector's report. February 26th, 1915.

Miss K.S.S. Upsdell, teacher of the Junior room had present 21 girls and 28 boys; a total of 49, all in the First Standard. After recess this teacher, for one hour takes both rooms in one classroom and teaches the children figures, the making of them, and also the doing of several sums on the blackboard. In Standard I, are all the grades, from knowing absolutely nothing to reading fairly well.

Miss Upsdell is qualified by two years at Goldsmith's Training College, University of London. Had four years of pupil teaching. Has special distinction on teaching and needlework. Has been teaching for five years in England and twelve months at Coblentz, Sask. and at Le Pas School for two months, has no normal training. Has a certificate from the Froebel Institute in London, England, Elementary and Part One of Higher.

Junior Room. Miss K.S.S. Upsdell, teacher. Present at inspection 26 girls and 14 boys. All in the first Standard. All the children are making good progress in reading, writing and Arithmetic. Sir,

Reference Departmental letter No 109-4-1, dated July 27th last, informing me that the Department had approved of the appointment of Rev. E.V. Bird to the position of teacher of the Fort a la Corne North Day School, and that Mrs Bird was receiving the appointment of Field Matron on the reserve.

I have the honour to report that while on James Smith's reserve on the 28th ultimo, I visited the school and met Rev Mr. & Mrs Bird.

When I arrived there at about three O'clock, P.M., I found Mr Bird engaged in repairing the fence around the buildings. Mrs Bird was in the classroom teaching. In conversation with them they informed me that Mrs Bird was a qualified teacher for the Province, and that she was the one who was to teach the school, that Rev. Mr. Bird who is doing Missionary work on the reserve was assisting her with her duties of Field Matron, and that should any cases of sickness arise which demanded her personal and immediate attention during class room hours, Mr Bird would take charge of the school during her absence. I replied that this did not agree with Departmental letter referred to above, which I had with me and showed them.

Rev. Mr Bird then informed me that he had a letter, which I understood was sent him through his Lordship, the Bishop of Saskatchewan's office at Prince Albert, which stated that the arrangement mentioned above was satisfactory and could be carried out.

At my request he offered to show me the letter, and while looking for same remembered that it had been returned to the Bishop's office.

Mrs Bird informed me that Mr. J.F. Hutchison, Inspector of Public Schools, had inspected her school during the past month.

REGINA, SASK. July 30th, 1928

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to report that when on the James Smith's Reserve, in the Duck Lake Agency, I visited the North Day School and noted its condition. There were no pupils present, as the holiday season is now on. The children are improving, but progress is slow. Mrs. Bird puts plenty of vim in her work and one would almost expect better results. However, the children are somewhat irregular in attendance and this no doubt retards progress.

The children were fairly well clothed, but were not tidy; in fact, I took occasion to point out that many of the children had not even combed their hair. I further noticed that the children sat down to the noon-day meal without washing, although they are provided with wash basins and towels. I had Mrs. Bird send them out to wash. She explained that the children always washed, but had just taken advantage on account of visitors.

The seats are of the old double type. Mrs. Bird remarked that as she had been unable to secure new seats through the Agent and Inspectors, she had written direct, and I understand new seats are being provided. These should be securely put together and fastened to slats on arrival, as otherwise, they will be knocked about and broken.

The outside windows were on, but the screens were still lying about outside. Mrs. Bird said they had been left out in order that they might be painted. This was no doubt true, but undoubtedly they had been neglected, and I found two or three broken.

The school and residence have both been painted this year, and the work is well done.

I was not altogether impressed with the work and conditions about the school, but we can hardly

expect a woman to act as teacher and Field Matron and find both positions satisfactorily filled. I would not wish to convey that the classroom work is greatly suffering, but I do believe the field work is, and I cannot see where the Department are receiving value for the salary paid as Field Matron, which is $480.00 per year. Memorandum - Concerning the Services of the Rev. E. V. Bird,
At present Teacher of the James Smith Indian Day School.

Rev. Mr. Bird was first employed by the Department at the Red Pheasant Indian Day School. He served there for 3 years, 1920-23, with considerable success. He applied for the principalship of the MacKay Indian Residential School and was given a fair trial there, somewhat against the advice of departmental officers. He was relieved of his duties in 1927, and Bishop Lloyd, when nominating him for the James Smith Indian Day School, stated that he had not been a success in the residential institution "as expected" (109-4-1). The appointment, of course, had been made by the M. S. C. O. The trouble which led to his removal from the MacKay School was in connection with corporal punishment. Both the Church and the Department investigated, and the Church, on its own initiative, relieved him of his post. (128-1-1).

From 1927, Mr. and Mrs. Bird were at the James Smith Indian Day School (Fort à la Corne North). In October, 1930, the Church notified the Department that Mrs. Burbridge, teacher of the south end of the reserve, was leaving. A month later, Mrs. Burbridge put up a fight against her retirement and complained of the activities of the Rev. Mr. Bird. (109-9-1). Mr. Bird retaliated in January, 1931, by interesting the Honourable Mr. Weir in his behalf. Further, Mrs. Bird wrote the Superintendent General, complaining of Indian Agent Schmidt (D. M.'s Private File 329) and she wrote the Department, protesting about the procedure in calling the medical officer to the reserve (9-109). In February, the Chief of the Band and the President of the Canadian Legion at Kinistino protested concerning Mrs. Burbridge's dismissal and complained about Mr. Bird. In March, Archdeacon Paul investigated conditions and found the reserve rather divided in its allegiance between the two workers (109-9-1). Mrs. Burbridge left in April, 1931.

In October, 1931, the Superintendent General asked the Department to remove Mr. Bird from the James Smith Indian Day School and arrangements have been made for him to leave in June, 1932. Bishop Hallam has had an interview with the Superintendent General and it was agreed that he would be transferred to the Sturgeon Lake Indian Day School.

Fort-a-la-Corne North Day School

This school is situated at the North end of the James Smith's Reserve. I visited it in the forenoon of March 10th.

The day was cold and a strong wind was blowing. I arrived at the school at 9:30 a.m. and found it warm and comfortable. There were 9 boys and 5 girls present out of an enrollment of 17. The ages of the children ranged from six to thirteen years. The different classes were examined in reading and they spoke in an audible voice and I considered the reading good. The children in the primary class were questioned regarding daily life and appeared quite bright. They answered questions without hesitation. The average attendance for the week of my visit was 14.

The children's hands and faces were clean and their clothing, although not new, was clean and I considered they were warmly clad.

The teacher, Mrs. McFarlane, I would judge, is well qualified to teach Indian children. Her manner is kindly and I am of the opinion that she is really interested in the children and sympathetic towards them. I may say that I had previously come in contact with Mrs. McFarlane at Onion Lake where she taught a white school, which the children of Departmental employees attended. She was highly spoken of there and her departure from the school to take up Indian work was a matter of deep regret in that community.

Mrs. McFarlane informs me that she is making preparation to plant a large garden and hopes to grow sufficient roots and vegetables to enable her to supplement the warm drink which has been allowed by the Department.

I found the school clean, but it is in need of redecoration. The cross light spoken of by Inspector Piercy, I am of the opinion, can be eliminated to a large extent, if not altogether, by providing dark blinds for the windows in the end of the classroom. I found the school clean and tidy. It is heated by a furnace. The radiation provided in connection with this furnace is different from any I have seen. The teacher informs me that...
informs me that she had difficulty at first in operating it and wrote to the Manufacturers, asking for instructions and since receiving full instructions from them she has had no difficulty in keeping the school warm. At the time of Inspector Piercy's visit she said she was having difficulty and on really cold windy days the school was not comfortable, but that condition has now been overcome.

I was very pleased indeed with conditions as I found them at this school. I would however be very reluctant to have anything I have said construed as a criticism of Inspector Piercy's report and will give him credit for reporting conditions as he found them, but I would say that conditions today I feel would not justify such severe criticism as he made. A very great change must have taken place in as much as I found things quite satisfactory. Here, as at other Reserves where day schools are in operation, the attendance is effected at times by cold weather, sickness, and in a few instances by the indifference of parents. Dear Sir:

Your letter of October 8, addressed to the Honourable T. A. Crerar, Minister of this Department, has been passed on to me for consideration and reply.

I may state that the desirability of establishing a superannuation fund, to which Indian day school teachers would contribute and from which they would be eligible for allowances, has been reviewed by departmental officials on a number of occasions in recent years. The obstacles, however, standing in the way of the establishment of such a fund are, in my judgment, for the time being at least, almost insurmountable.

I was responsible, a few years ago, for the establishment of a superannuation fund for teachers in the province of Manitoba, and I entered this Department two years ago, hopeful that a worthwhile fund could be established here.

May I point out that approximately 50% of Indian pupils are enrolled at residential schools, operated by certain churches, in cooperation with the Department. The principals and teachers responsible for instruction in these institutions are employed, not by the Government, but by the churches. A large majority of Indian day schools are also operated by the Government, in close cooperation with the churches. The records here disclose that 50% of the Indian population in Canada belong to the Roman Catholic Church. This means that a great many of our Indian day schools, particularly in eastern Canada, are in charge of teachers -

Willis A. Richford, Esq.,
Teacher,
James Smith Indian Day School,
Kinistino, Sask.
teachers who are members of religious Communities or religious Teaching Orders. These religious Orders, I understand, have made provision for the care and welfare of their members in the declining years of their lives, with the result that these Sisters would not be at all interested in a superannuation fund to which they would be compelled to contribute.

You may be interested to learn that the average period of time spent by our teachers in Indian day schools is a little less than five years. This means that a great many young unmarried women seek and secure positions as Indian day school teachers with the object of getting married in the course of a few years. These girls would hesitate to contribute to a fund such as the Civil Service Superannuation Fund, if they were informed that no contributions would be returned until they had spent at least ten years in the service of the Government.

I am personally of the opinion that, in order to qualify for superannuation, Indian day and residential school teachers would have to become permanent Civil Servants as defined by the Civil Service Act. In view of all the circumstances, however, the chance of our Indian day and residential school teachers becoming permanent Civil Servants, appointed after qualifying by competitive examination, is very remote indeed.

There is a widespread feeling that Indian day school teachers are, somehow or other, discriminated against by the Government, in that the teachers do not qualify for superannuation. May I state that there are thousands of individuals in the Service of the Government, none of whom qualify under the Superannuation Act. I have in mind temporary Civil Servants employed for years either at Ottawa or in the outside service - post masters throughout the Dominion, temporary light-house keepers and a number of others. These claim - and I think rightly so - that their case should be given consideration before any attempt -
attempt is made to review the claims of, say, residential school teachers, who are not even employed by the Government. My personal sympathies, of course, are all with the teachers, but I think you will readily appreciate the difficulties confronting the officials when the matter is referred to them for consideration.

I may state, however, that the salaries paid throughout the Dominion to Indian day school teachers in recent years, when free housing accommodation is taken into account, have been almost double the salaries paid to public school teachers. I am not suggesting that the salaries paid are too high, but I do think this fact should be kept in mind, in fairness to the Dominion Government, when a superannuation scheme, or schemes, come up for consideration.

It is my hope that you may have an opportunity of discussing this matter with Dr. Robertson, Inspector of Indian Agencies, province of Saskatchewan. Dr. Robertson is reasonably familiar with the attempts we have made to solve this problem and would, I feel sure, be glad of an opportunity to discuss the matter with you.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA,

James Smith Indian Day School North

At the time of my visit to this institution there were 15 children in attendance and there were 23 children on the register. It was explained to me by the teacher that the school attendance was small because the children were away from the reservation with their parents. There were also some children away from school with skin trouble and these were to be seen by the doctor.

Mr. McLeod, the Indian Agent, accompanied me, and I brought to his attention that he should see to it that the attendance at the school improves as soon as the Indians return to the reserve, which I know he will do.

The classes taught at this school are from 1 to 7 and in Grade 7 there are just two boys.

The school had just been renovated and seemed to be in fair shape. The teacher's house needed repairs but the material was there and the work will be gone on immediately to fix up the interior of the school house.

The teacher, as you know, is an Indian girl from the Sandy Lake Reserve in the Carlton Agency who is married to one of the Indians from the James Smith Reserve, namely John Robert McLeod. He is at present in the Army but was at home on leave when I was there. As far as I could make out from talking to the Indian Agent, etc., Mrs. McLeod is now getting along fairly well. Mr. McLeod, the Agent, and Cannon Ahenakew who is stationed on the James Smith Reserve, had a round up with the teachers and since then I understand that they are attending to their work better and things are fairly satisfactory.

In passing I might mention that after the war I think the proper thing to do with the school and teacher's residence is to give the material to some of the Indians and build a new school and teacher's residence because these buildings have been there for a great number of years and always need a lot of repairing as something is always...........
repairing as something is always going wrong. The above would be my recommendations, that is, those two buildings be replaced as soon as funds and material are available.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.
Regina, October 31st, 1944.

Dear Bishop Martin:

I have your letter of the 8th instant, with reference to Mrs. McLeod giving up duties at the James Smith Day School at the end of the current month. Her resignation is accepted and the Indian Agent will be informed accordingly.

I note your suggestion that Mrs. Ahenakew be engaged on a temporary basis and, if you are unable to secure a better qualified teacher, we approve of her temporary appointment, but it should be understood that if at any time within the next few months the services of a qualified teacher become available she will be prepared to relinquish the school without objection. In any case I feel that you will agree that she should not be retained after June 30, 1946. We have been allowing the preceding teacher $85 a teaching month, but I feel that $75 a teaching month, plus bonus, should be sufficient for Mrs. Ahenakew. There will be no deduction for income tax, as she is an Indian working on a reserve.

Yours very truly,

Acting Director.

Rt. Rev. H.D. Martin, D.D.,
Bishop of Saskatchewan,
Synod Office,
Prince Albert, Sask.
Ottawa,
December 15, 1944.

Mr. N.J. McLeod, Acting Indian Agent, Duck Lake, Sask.

I am advised by Bishop Martin that Mrs. Ida McLeod, teacher of the James Smith Day School, finds it necessary to give up her duties at the end of the current month. We are advising Bishop Martin that her resignation is accepted.

Owing to the difficulty in obtaining a qualified teacher, we have decided to accept the Bishop's recommendation regarding the temporary employment of Mrs. L. Ahenakew. In this connection I enclose, for your information, a copy of our letter to Bishop Martin. I enclose the necessary forms which you should have Mrs. Ahenakew complete and return. It is understood that her employment will be effective from January 1, 1945.

For Deputy Minister.
